SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill fulfils the promises made by the coalition in its election policy statement, Better Pay for Better Work . Before the 1993 election, the Australian Labor Party disguised its policy intentions and, after the election, betrayed the confidences of the Australian people. They legislated the most pro‐union laws ever introduced into Australia. They did so at the insistence of the ACTU.

The contrast with the coalition's legislation could not be more stark. The pre‐election guarantee we gave workers was that we would keep awards and the Industrial Relations Commission and if you entered an agreement you would not be worse off than under the award. Today we make our guarantee the law and present a balanced system not dictated by some special interest group but a system fair for both employers and employees.

Our new act is built on: commitments to a more direct relationship between employers and employees with a much reduced role for third party intervention; a fair go for all so that the system is appropriately balanced and delivers benefits for both employees and employers; genuine freedom of association and greater choice of union representation; a more accessible system; and a stronger sense of the rights and responsibilities of parties in the industrial relations system. The government remains committed to these principles. The bill, as amended, implements them. The task is now for employees and employers to use the opportunities the bill offers them.

Under the legislation we have delivered what we said we would deliver. We have delivered an award system which will provide a safety net of fair minimum wages and conditions with benefits beyond it generally being a matter for agreement at the enterprise or workplace level. We have delivered a system in which there will be more effective flexibility for parties in reaching agreements, a genuine choice of agreements, formal and informal, union and non‐union, individual and collective. That is, we have put in place enabling legislation—legislation which is designed purposefully to avoid prescription and to enable employers and employees to find a home in the system which suits their particular needs.

We do not favour one agreement stream over another. We do not want to corral employers and employees into one end of the system and boast that as a government we have achieved some remarkable success. We simply want to give them the general flexibility of the jurisdiction established by the legislation so that they can get what they want from the system.

PARA.BREAK: We have also formally introduced into the federal industrial relations system an individ ual agreement stream. This is a long overdue but profoundly significant change in emphasis in the jurisdiction. Not so long ago this would have seemed an inconceivable proposition at the Commonwealth level. It is an initiative that, for political reasons only, has been resisted by those on the other side of the House and by the trade union movement, but the needs of the modern workplace for simplicity, flexibility and closer direct relations between workers and their employers have won out. It is a new agreement stream which minimises third party intervention. It is designed, subject to a safety net, to get workers into jobs without delay, without conflict between award parties and without costly litigation.

SPEECH.PARA: For many employers and employees Australian workplace agreements will symbolise that it is now safe to come back into the industrial relations system again. As a new option, Australian workplace agreements will change the character of the federal system. The system is no longer exclusively about registered organisations and collective bargaining; it is now about workers and employers and their particular and local needs. The bill's objects reinforce this, along with other amendments to the certified agreement and award streams which seek to emphasise the views of employers and their employees rather than those of tribunals and third parties.

We have also delivered genuine freedom of association founded on effective protection against coercion or discrimination based on an individual's membership or non‐membership of a union. Mr Speaker, I am delighted to say that today we abolished compulsory unionism. We have also delivered changes which will increase choice and accountability in relation to registered organisations.

In making these changes, we invited registered organisations into the world of competition and improved service delivery for their members. Legislated privilege and monopoly rights have a dwindling relevance to modernity. Employers and employees will always have representational needs, and the bill embraces this concept firmly. But, equally, employers and employees deserve a quality return on the financial and personal trust that they place in organisations.

For all their declining membership base, the government has given unions their last best chance to square themselves with workers. The bill is not anti‐union, despite what some union leaders say. The bill provides unions with a shot at building their status as responsible organisations which provide a professional service geared to the contemporary workplace and the contemporary work force.

We have delivered legislation which will ensure that appropriate standards of industrial conduct are observed. There will be a more effective regime to ensure that agreements are honoured. The commission's powers to curtail unlawful industrial action have been strengthened and secondary boycott provisions have been restored. (Extension of time granted)

We have recognised the right to take industrial action. We have also ensured that both parties in the industrial system have proper regard for their responsibilities to one another and the wider community. We have delivered a workable system for dealing with unfair dismissal on the basis of a fair go all round and, in doing so, we have expressed an overwhelming community consensus that the previous Brereton system did nothing more than stifle employment growth and create division in the workplace. This was Labor's legacy, and the government has buried it.

Under this government, harmonisation of federal and state systems of industrial relations is being pursued through complementary legislation and through a cooperative approach to administrative arrangements and service delivery. Again, the government is conscious of the need to gear industrial relations systems at all levels to the needs of the users. Industrial relations systems should not be characterised by institutionalisation of bureaucracy and undue process. Consistent with the forces affecting all areas of government at all levels, the system as a whole should be about delivering services to its users, ensuring their ease of access and providing quick and effective responses.

This approach has affected many aspects of the bill, and it is an important force for future change. But it has had a more recent impact as well. This week the Victorian government moved legislatively to refer its powers over industrial relations to the Commonwealth. This sends a powerful message about the leadership of the Victorian government. It does, too, provide a vote of confidence in this government's vision of the workplace as embedded in this legislation. It is also an eminently practical decision which will ensure that businesses in Victoria will be able to consolidate their industrial relations strategies under the federal system and boost their efficiency as a result.

Small and medium‐sized businesses will be able to use federal arrangements for Australian workplace agreements or for collective agreements without the need for an award if that is their wish, and without the need to become embroiled in the jurisdictional and constitutional complexities which have dogged their quest for flexibility and productivity. This symbolises the capacity of governments to make real and substantial improvements in the way in which users interface with the industrial relations system.

Similarly, the bill provides that employees and employers should have the right to choose whether they wish to be covered by an award or agreement in the state or the federal jurisdiction. The amendments to the provisions dealing with federal‐state coverage maintain this principle. They continue to allow choice between federal awards and state employment agreements provided that the relevant state legislation contains certain protections for employees.

In opening new options in the agreement stream in the changes to the role of organisations under the bill, in the harmonisation initiatives being undertaken by the government, in wearing down the borders between state and Commonwealth industrial relations jurisdictions, the government is demonstrating that the wider system can genuinely work for the benefit of its users—that is, that this industrial relations system can and should work in the context of modern standards of service delivery and best practice.

The government also believes that the workplace relations system which its legislation establishes is appropriately balanced and delivers benefits for both employers and employees. We have had lengthy discussions with the Australian Democrats about the concerns they had in relation to some of the arrangements proposed by the government in its original bill. In these discussions there was a common respect for principle and a common commitment to making the legislation work for all Australians. I congratulate the Democrats on the cooperative and positive approach that they brought to this task, and thank them for the manner in which our discussions and negotiations were conducted.

It is important to rebut the misrepresentation that the government's industrial relations policy is a low wage policy. The aim of the reforms is not to cut wages and conditions, but to promote higher productivity and a more flexible labour market and so provide the opportunity for higher wages and better conditions for workers. This, after all, was where the government staked its ground in its election policy statement, Better Pay for Better Work, which was so resoundingly affirmed by the Australian people on 2 March.

The pressing need for genuine labour market reform to which this bill gives strong support is highlighted by Australia's dismal productivity performance over the last decade and a half. According to the OECD, between 1979 and 1995 Australia's annual rate of growth in labour productivity averaged a meagre 1.4 per cent.

This was below the OECD average and far behind rates of productivity growth recorded in some of the dynamic economies to our north. These years of dismal productivity growth largely coincided with the era of centralised wage fixation. The pick‐up in our productivity performance to the extent that we have had it in recent years with the introduction of enterprise bargaining, even on Labor's flawed model, goes to show the enormous potential gains which will flow from a genuine program of labour market reform such as ours.

PARA.BREAK: Only through genuine reform can we secure the productivity improvement that is necessary to underpin continued employment growth and a sustainable rise in living stand ards for all Australians. (Extension of time granted) In view of this, the award system will operate as a safety net of minimum wages and conditions. The detailed mechanism for its adjustment is being left within the jurisdiction of the commission.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of factors which the commission will be required to have regard to when it is adjusting the safety net. These include a range of economic considerations: productivity, inflation and unemployment. It will have to consider the needs of the low paid, equal pay and the need to prevent discrimination.

The commission will also need to ensure that any alterations to wage relativities between awards are based on skill, responsibility and the conditions under which work is performed. This requirement recognises the importance of relativities between awards for the viability of the award wage system in ensuring its capacity both to maintain the stability and equity of the system and to provide ongoing net protection. The government's legislation does not extend, however, to internal relativities within awards. Indeed, the emphasis which we are proposing, and in particular the focus on the low paid and minimum safety net, may involve some compression of internal relativities. Such compression has occurred in the past when the commission has awarded flat dollar increases in award rates.

In addition, while stable relativities between awards are important for the workability of the system and for their safety net role, the government anticipates that, over time, there will be increasing diversity in actual pay relationships as a result of the emphasis of the system on agreement making. Wages and conditions need to increasingly reflect local needs and circumstances. Similarly, in future, when maintaining the safety net, regard must be had by the commission when altering wage relativities between awards to the skill, responsibility and the conditions under which work is performed. That is, the bill consigns to the deeper past still the notions of automatic wage flow‐on between awards and comparative wage justice.

BREAK.PARA: The focusing of the award system on the provision of minimum terms and conditions of employment will apply to all awards, regardless of their customary status as either minimum rates or paid rates. All awards will be simplified. The same allowable matters and the same process and timing will apply. There will not be new paid rates awards. Over time, and following consultation between the parties, it is expected that existing paid rates structures will be phased out and translated into minimum rates arrangements under the supervision of the commission.

Transitional provisions in the bill work to ensure that overall pay entitlements are not reduced as part of such conversion process. Wages and conditions beyond the minimum safety net will be a matter for the parties themselves to settle through enterprise and workplace agreements. In exceptional circumstances, there is provision for special case arbitration in certain critical dispute situations and in situations where paid rates awards have customarily applied.

However, this is only where all efforts to reach an agreement have been exhausted and the exceptional nature of any fixed term arbitration undertaken in these circumstances is reflected in the conditions that apply, including consideration by a full bench of the public interest, how productivity might be improved and the conduct of the negotiating parties. In addition, any resultant award will not generally be able to be varied or to form part of the benchmark for the no disadvantage test for any subsequent bargaining.

Strong incentives are maintained in the workplace relations framework generally to focus the system on agreement making rather than recourse to the commission. Even then, conciliation must be exhausted so that any arbitration other than general adjustments to the safety net will be a last resort confined to special and isolated cases. The expectation is that most parties who have been on paid rates awards will be covered by agreements. This is not new, as employees covered by paid rates awards have generally made the transition to enterprise bargaining so that their actual terms and conditions are now determined by agreements, rather than awards.

Amendments to the bill also provide that award minima will act as the benchmark for the tests which are to apply to formalised agreements. In order to be formalised, all agreements will now be required to satisfy a modified version of the existing no disadvantage test. In the light of the move to the vetting of AWAs provided for in the amendments agreed with the Democrats and against the background of the award simplification process, the government believes that the new no disadvantage test provides a practical way of delivering the government's commitments while affording considerable flexibility to the parties.

In this context, the legislation makes it clear that the no disadvantage test is a global one. That is, the test is whether an agreement would result in a reduction in the overall terms and conditions of employees to be covered. The government's intention is that, apart from this overall assessment, flexibility not be constrained. Subject only to the global test, employers and employees are now at liberty to strike genuinely innovative agreements without any contrivances or artificial restrictions.

It would be up to the Employment Advocate or the commission to weigh up the respective elements of the different components of a proposed agreement in deciding whether there was any disadvantage to employees in their overall terms and conditions of employment. Different sorts of considerations might be relevant in different contexts. As such, any term or condition of employment may be negotiated and dealt with by agreement, provided it is consistent with the act.

The government's approach to the reform of workplace relations in Australia retains an important role for the commission, whose status and involvement will continue to be integral to the effective working of our system of workplace relations. (Extension of time granted) The commission's role will be different in a number of important respects under the new legislation as employers and employees increasingly take responsibility for their own industrial relations and agreement making and awards become a safety net of minimum wages and conditions.

The commission will have a particular role in ensuring the establishment and maintenance of the award safety net, encouraging the making of certified agreements, overseeing the conduct of workplace bargaining for certified agreements and ensuring that the parties to such agreements and awards comply with their industrial responsibilities and obligations. It will have responsibility for managing the simplification for the award safety net and for encouraging the spread of and improved access to part‐time work with pro rata conditions and reasonable predictability of working hours.

The amendments to the bill do broaden the commission's role in several respects, but we have focused the commission's role, particularly and importantly for the benefit of the low paid. The government's submission to the commission, foreshadowed last weekend by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), is yet again evidence of our concern for the low paid, both in respect of the wages which they receive and their prospects of both retaining the jobs they have and for the unemployed securing a job in the future.

Where the commission has a role in intervening beyond the minimum safety net of allowable award matters, the legislation ensures that this is appropriately circumscribed so that the focus of the system on agreement making at the enterprise and workplace levels is maintained. There are a number of criteria that will have to be met before the commission can make such orders. These are intended to ensure that the jurisdiction is confined to exceptional matters and that there is no reasonable prospect of their being settled by agreement.

The exceptional matters orders include a requirement that they relate to a single matter and apply to only a single business unless the commission is satisfied that an application is appropriate. Such acceptable matters provisions cannot undermine the award simplification process, or the strong emphasis of the legislation on the role of awards as setting minimum wages and conditions overall, while actual wage determination is principally managed through formal or informal agreements made at the workplace level.

I have often referred to the consultative process which began before the election last March and has led to the legislation which will be concluded today. It was a process which included employers, employer organisations, unions, the ACTU, governments—state and territory—women's organisations and churches, and ethnic community and welfare groups. We have benefited considerably from their comments and suggestions—we have taken many on board—and the government is grateful for their effort and involvement.

At the same time, some individual organisations and people who took part in that process do stand out in terms of the depth, consistency and strength of their ongoing contribution to the development of the bill. It is appropriate today that their names go on the record. In particular, I wish to acknowledge the contributions of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Bryan Noakes and Reg Hamilton provided very constructive and important support throughout the process. The ACTU were very involved through the committee on industrial legislation. I particularly acknowledge the work done by Tim Pallas and John Cairns in that respect. Our thanks go to the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Retailers Association, the National Farmers Federation and the Labour Council of New South Wales, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Brendan Macarthy, the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Michael Angwin, Professor Charles Mulvey, Paul Houlihan and Dr Chris Jessup QC.

I am also grateful to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel for continuing to provide us with consistently high quality legislative drafting against very short deadlines. I also thank the Department of Industrial Relations, which has throughout the process demonstrated its professionalism, capacity for authoritative technical advice and openness to innovative approaches to policy and institutional reforms and for, above all, its singular ability to provide a quality service to the government of the day.

I also particularly want to acknowledge the work done by my ministerial staff in the process prior to the election and throughout a very long eight months. To Peter Richards, my chief of staff; to Jonathan Hamberger, who worked for me once before as an adviser on industrial relations and who is a specialist par excellence in this field, and to Nick Hordern, who worked with me both as a policy adviser and as a media adviser all through the process—my special and grateful thanks. Thanks also go to my other ministerial staff who provided great support and worked many hours to see the successful conclusion of this bill.

The task for the reformist is not over. The policy debate must go on. For business and for employers and employees the pressing task is to take advantage of the opportunities provided by the new laws. The government, in its role as an employer, needs to address its own human resources strategy. We also need to encourage better practices in key industries like the waterfront, construction and meat processing industries and other industries.

I place on record my thanks to the Prime Minister and to my colleagues for the support that they have given me in this process. Lastly, I thank the Australian people for the confidence with which they trusted us to present this bill and to see its successful carriage today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence in the tone that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) concluded—it might be the only thing about which we agree—and to thank some people for their contribution to the debate which led to us dealing with these amendments today. I particularly thank Senator Sherry and the Labor senators for their excellent and diligent work throughout a very complex process of dealing with these and many other amendments which were not successful in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the clerks in the House and the Senate for their great assistance to the opposition in a very complex task of drafting, which they did very effectively and conscientiously. On behalf of all my Labor colleagues here and in the Senate, I thank David Fredericks for the work he did in assisting us in the drafting of these amendments and in the processing and management of them.

The opposition recognises what is, for it, an unpleasant political reality that these amendments mean that this flawed and unfair bill has been passed by the Senate with many of its worst features intact and its original criticisms still valid. Our original criticisms were very lengthy. I made a half‐hour speech, we moved 300 amendments and many of our colleagues spoke, so I will not repeat all that. But our concerns came down to three core principles. Our concerns were that this bill undermined the Industrial Relations Commission, it undermined the award system and it undermined the rights of workers to organise. All these three concerns continue, slightly modified in some instances. But, even after these amendments, those concerns are still valid.

The Industrial Relations Commission, for example, has lost its general jurisdiction to arbitrate to settle industrial disputes. The significance of that change to industrial relations in Australia and many aspects of our economy and society in future is a remarkable thing which I think most Australians are not aware of. That has gone, despite the assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the Industrial Relations Commission would keep its powers.

For every worker working in Australia now, the award system, which has underpinned and been the vehicle for advancement of workers' wages and conditions for generations, has played some, if not the total, role in determining wages and working conditions. They are now stripped back as a result of these amendments to 20 allowable matters rather than merely 18—but the balance still disappears in 18 months. The clock has started ticking for so many fundamental award conditions for Australian workers, despite the Prime Minister's guarantee that no worker would lose their award conditions.

The right to organise is still at risk, most particularly due to, simply summarised, the massive increases in penalties and punishments and the easier access to these sanctions rather than the use of the conciliation and arbitration process to which Australians have become accustomed and which has been part of the cooperative process leading to, in recent years, a record low level of industrial disputes. This is, unfortunately, already showing signs of increasing under the industrial relations management of this government, even before we run into the problems that this bill might generate.

Of course, the strongest and the best organised workers will win their lost conditions back. Some already have a guarantee to that effect. But for others—those who need the award protections most, those who need the Industrial Relations Commission most, those who need the support of the collective organisations that represent them most—these provisions will be gone forever. Many workers, many workplaces, will be back to 20 basic conditions.

Think of the circumstances in which the workers find themselves when trying to negotiate to win these conditions back. The person with whom they are negotiating knows that if no agreement is reached the conditions disappear. There is no imperative on the employer to agree at all. Many reasonable employers will. But the point of it is that the fundamental protections that these awards provide are against the activities of unreasonable employers, and they are the ones who are empowered by this bill.

So much for the rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off. Not that that should be a surprise, of course, because we have already established quite clearly that under the government's submission to the Industrial Relations Commission, to which the minister referred in his speech, low paid workers will be $1,000 a year worse off than they would have been under the proposals of the previous Labor government. So much for the fact that no worker would be worse off. (Extension of time granted)

Where does that leave us after the passage of the workplace relations bill? It still leaves us with a fundamentally flawed bill. It still leaves us with an unfair bill. It still leaves us with a bill that undermines the three pillars of Australian industrial relations which have protected Australian workers. It leaves us with the Prime Minister's promises to workers during the election campaign lying in a crumpled heap, just next to those from the budget and the other broken promises.

Looking forward, where do we go to from here? Strenuous as our opposition to this bill continues to be, it will become the law quite soon. Despite our continuing opposition, that will occur. How are we to look forward to measure the success or failure of this bill? We have found people running away very hard from the idea of what criteria should be set to measure the success of this bill. We have had a few comments about what should not be used. Let me make some suggestions of criteria, apart from the Prime Minister's two promises that no worker would be worse off and no worker would lose their award conditions. What are other broader social and economic criteria?

Will there be fewer industrial disputes over this three‐year term under this regime than there were in the last three years under the old regime? Each time I raise this, the media likes to interpret it as some sort of forecast of industrial war. I am not predicting industrial Armageddon. The signs at the moment are not encouraging about what is going to happen in terms of the number of industrial disputes in Australia, but there is still time—even under this bill—for the government to adopt a cooperative approach that would not lead to a major increase in industrial disputes. The signs are not very optimistic, either about the current trends or about this bill, but let us wait and see and measure this bill against that criterion first.

Perhaps more importantly, will there be more jobs created in this parliamentary term under this regime than there were in the last term of the parliament? Particularly, will there be more jobs created in small business?

On the social criterion of fairness, will the distribution of wage outcomes and benefits be fairer after this bill than it was before it? Will the gap between high and low incomes narrow or widen? Will the gap between male and female incomes narrow or widen? The sign are not good, but let us see.

PARA.BREAK: We have had great emphasis on how this will boost productivity. Will labour produc tivity increase faster after this bill than the current trend rate of 1.75 per cent per annum? I think that is unlikely, but let us see.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the broader economic objectives with regard to continuing growth, will the overall wage outcomes be more consistent with the low inflation, low interest rate environment than the outcomes under the present system? It may be that over time other criteria will be set. But it seems to me that is not a bad starting point against which to measure the success of this proposed new industrial relations regime. At least these criteria of success look for positive outcomes. I note that the minister has recently raised some criteria that are essentially negative—criteria that he will not use. For example, he said he would not be measuring the success of the legislation by simply counting the number of employees covered by AWAs. That is a bit of an irony, because we remember the same person constantly saying that enterprise flexibility agreements were clearly a failure because they had not been used in any significant numbers. It is interesting to ask why the minister is retreating from applying the same standard to his new Australian workplace agreement stream, and we will look to see how many people take up these proposals.

I also asked the minister previously in the parliament to give us an assurance, because of the great job benefits he sees in this bill, that the government will create more than 500,000 jobs in small business in this term. He has not yet given that assurance. We continue to seek it. We will monitor with interest the outcomes in that regard. I think it is highly unlikely that it is a goal that can be achieved; nevertheless, it is a very significant criterion for every Australian family, for every Australian unemployed worker, for all those in employment who are concerned about their employment security. (Extension of time granted)

PARA.BREAK: The principle concern is, at its core, even after these inadequate, unsatisfactory amendments, this is a bill which fundamentally misunderstands the nature of the labour market. It continues to be predicated on the assumption of equality of bargaining power in the workplace between employers and em ployees. That assumption is so fundamentally flawed—so obviously flawed to anyone who has been on a workplace floor for more than five minutes, or spoken to workers rather than spoken at them, who has listened to workers—that it is hard to believe that you could build an edifice on such a flawed structure.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the fundamental flaws of that structure that permeate every element of this bill. It is what inevitably means, however one measures the intentions of those who initiated the bill or those who negotiated the amendments, that the outcome of this process must be fundamentally flawed and can be only an unfair outcome because of the absolute failure to recognise that aspect of the labour market and the need for elements of this legislation to cope with the consequences of that fundamental difference in bargaining power in the workplace.

It is those problems and that circumstance that pervades this bill and means that it has the regressive social consequences about which we are so apprehensive without having the capacity to deliver the economic benefits which the government seeks.

Secondly, looking prospectively, going beyond the immediate concerns, this bill absolutely fails to address, and by its inactivity will exacerbate, the biggest issue in workplaces today. It is none of the things the minister has spoken about. When you go into workplaces and talk to workers, when you look at the surveys that the Department of Industrial Relations itself does—and I suspect when you look at the market research the Liberal Party does—the biggest issue for Australian workers today is the increased stress and insecurity in their workplaces. Workers say they are having to work harder, having to work longer and are feeling less secure because circumstances continue to change under their feet every day. They find themselves negotiating away conditions that they value to preserve living standards that they need. They feel that they cannot see in the future the security to which they have aspired. There is a significant emergence of bargaining fatigue.

Even those who have done very well under enterprise bargaining—and that is not all—are flagging under the pressure of being called upon to do it again and again. Under this bill, they are called upon to enter into an extra round of enterprise bargaining merely to win back conditions that are currently guaranteed to them under their award. I can assure the House—particularly the government members—that I have not found a worker who is looking forward to a round of enterprise bargaining to win back their award conditions that the government has arbitrarily taken away from them by this legislation. The Democrats have conspired in having taken those away from them, with only the most meagre—but welcome—modifications.

This bill fails to address the most profound issue affecting workers in their workplaces today—the issue of stress and insecurity. By its inadvertence and by its increased emphasis on the nature of the negotiations at the workplace, the increased need for enterprise bargaining and workplace bargaining, that insecurity and that stress will be increased. All the evidence from Victoria and Western Australia, where there has been increased emphasis in this way on individual contracts and on the nature of bargaining fundamentally underpinning Australian workplace agreements, has been that the stress, the insecurity, the pressure and the working hours for workers under those agreements have gone up.

That leads me to the third point about the future. This bill fundamentally ignores the emerging issue of working hours and the fair distribution of work in our society. With the changes being made, we are finding that working hours for those in work are going up while more and more Australians are either seeking work or seeking increased hours of work. (Extension of time granted) As with the minister, I will make sure this is my last extension. I thank the House for its agreement.
As we are debating the amendments that the government has moved and the bill as a consequence, I might continue to talk about that. It might cause you concern but I might do so.

There is a very serious issue emerging which all governments should be addressing and which people with social concern need to give consideration to and which the Labor Party in opposition will be developing policies about as a response and to put to the people. It is this issue of the fair distribution of work, the fact that those in work are working longer hours while more and more Australians are either seeking work or seeking more hours of work. It is a profound issue, it is an important issue.

While this bill does nothing about it, all the trends measured in the response to individual workplace agreements of the type reflected in this legislation lead to increased working hours. The Western Australian experience makes that clear. The Victorian experience makes that clear.

An objective observer would need to accept that the political management of the process of negotiation with the Democrats has been adroit. It is not necessarily a political plus for the government in the long term. Any objective observer would say it has been a political plus for the Minister for Industrial Relations inside the government, particularly in his competition with the Treasurer (Mr Costello). You would have to say there is one achievement out of these amendments. They have enhanced the relative status of the Minister for Industrial Relations vis‐a‐vis the Treasurer and anything that sets back the Treasurer's political career has to have something going for it.

Clearly, you can see the advantage to Mr Reith within the Liberal Party. It might have been smart politics but it is very bad industrial relations. That, I remind the minister, is actually his job. I know his principle preoccupation is his position within the government but his job is to improve industrial relations in Australia and with this bill, even after these amendments which do marginally improve the bill that went through the House, he still failed to deliver on that.

PARA.BREAK: I look forward to the opportunity, having reluctantly to accept the reality that this will become the law in this country, to reviewing its progress against the five benchmarks I have set down and the Prime Minister's two promises—the rock solid guarantee. You would have thought a rock solid guarantee might have been a core promise but, obvious ly, it was a non‐core promise. You would have thought the commitment that no worker would lose their award conditions might have been a core promise but, obviously, it was a non‐core promise.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition does not support accepting these amendments. While we recognise that they make the bill better than that which passed the House of Representatives, they do not go anywhere near far enough to improve this bill to make it an acceptable package for us. They leave us with a bill that is socially regressive, industrially disruptive and economically irrelevant. For those reasons, we will not be supporting the motion to accept these amendments and my colleagues will be seeking to support me in expressing the depth of our opposition to the bill which is emerging as a result of the Senate's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) for agreeing to the gag. This is absolutely unprecedented and delightful. Well done. Thank you, Simon.

SPEECH.PARA: This is indeed an historic occasion. It has been some 10 years, perhaps 12 altogether, since the initial divide in the industrial relations debate in this country. Members will recall that, for decade after decade, largely both sides of politics supported the centralised command driven model of industrial relations. Both sides of politics supported national wage cases. Both sides of politics supported a system where employers and employees were kept apart from each other in negotiations about their conditions of employment and indeed about their wages.

It was in 1984 that my side of politics finally started to set a divide in the political debate in Australia. In setting that divide, increasingly, my side of politics has seen a need to move to a more modern and open system, to devolve industrial relations back to the parties where it really matters—that is, the parties at the individual work circumstance that happens to exist.

The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill we are discussing today goes a long way towards achieving that objective. It is another step in the train of devolution of responsibility from central arbitral bodies back to the central players, the real players—that is, the work force and the management in all the businesses around Australia.

One of the things I noticed today as I looked at the Notice Paper is that it is 21 November 1996. I recall that it was on 21 April 1993 that the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, went to an Institute of Company Directors meeting in Melbourne and made two basic propositions. He said, firstly, that the award system was too complex, that it was too full of minutiae and that the awards ought to be simplified. He said that the awards should be brought down to basic core conditions as a safety net for conditions of employment in Australia. He did not say anything about having a single national minimum wage, like the United States. What he said was that awards should be simplified and brought back to core conditions. I have to say that this legislation now accomplishes what the then Prime Minister on 21 April 1993 said should happen.

The second major point that Paul Keating made in that address to the Institute of Company Directors was that, where workplaces were largely non-unionised—and I have to say that is the bulk of workplaces in our country; certainly 75 per cent, and perhaps more, of the private sector workplaces in Australia are non-unionised—there should be an opportunity for those employees and their employers to negotiate agreements outside the formalised industrial relations system, leaving aside the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and leaving aside the formal arbitral process. But he also said that there should be some minimum standard set of conditions described by the award to underpin that.

Literally, this legislation brings to fruition what the then Prime Minister, the then leader of the Labor Party—the party which now sits in opposition—wanted to accomplish. It seems to me an unbelievable dichotomy that the Labor Party sits there and argues hour after hour, point after point, against these basic propositions that its then leader, its Prime Minister, proposed to the nation.

I recall that the present member for Kingsford-Smith, Laurie Brereton, wanted to implement what Paul Keating said should happen but Laurie Brereton was prevented by the union leaders from continuing down that path. We have picked up the option based on our policy differential, which we started in 1984 and which has continued since that day, to try to change the system, to make a more cooperative workplace culture, to make Australia more productive, to make our industry more efficient and to make more jobs for Australians. (Time expired)

In New Zealand, for example, it is very clear that under these workplace agreements, which resemble what has been agreed with the Democrats here, women are the ones most likely to trade off hours, which makes it more difficult for them to meet family responsibilities. TALK.START.PARA: —This is not New Zealand.

—Because of concerns about the trends that were evident in New Zealand and concerns amongst women here on our side of politics—including our minister of the day—that there might be some deterioration in women's positions under enterprise bargaining, and certainly under workplace agreements, a flexible working hours and women's project was undertaken under the Sex Discrimination Act. The work that was done there shows very clearly what has been shown elsewhere. In investigating the range of changes made to working time arrangements in enterprise agreements, the effects on women's lives of demands for increasing flexibility and hours were very clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Women even now have been trading off hours and conditions in a way that is not true of men. That has a lot to do with the way women's work is constructed. They are more likely to be in non-unionised areas of work, they are more likely to work in isolation and they are less likely to have the protection of awards. In other words, they are already subject to the winds that you would now have blow over the entire Australian community. For example, in Western Australia, where you have had workplace agreements now for some time, there has been some improvement in men's wages: they have traded them off against hours and other flexibility. But, in the case of women, they have traded off the hours, they have reduced flexibility and there is more shift work and weekend work—without increases in pay. Women's wages in Western Australia are now well below the national average whereas men's wages are above it. In other words, the dispersion and the difference are growing under the sort of system that has now been embraced by the government and, I must say to my great disappointment, by the Democrats.

The Democrats would have us believe that they are very sympathetic to women in our community. They make much of the fact that theirs is a largely female party, both in its representation and in its membership. Yet they have, by negotiation with the government, clearly delivered to the women of Australia a significant deterioration in working conditions.

It is very clear that not only the work undertaken under the flexible working hours and women's project but also the 1995 report of the Industrial Relations Commission on enterprise bargaining, which was recently released after a long delay, show a large amount of information that confirms what I have been saying. They are trading off flexibility.

When you ask women what they want in the workplace they say that they would prefer predictability: they would prefer to work Monday to Friday, nine to five. What is happening—

TALK.START.PARA: —You casualised them.

—This is for full‐time workers. These are the effects that are already occurring for full-time workers. They have less control over their working lives and they, not surprisingly, resent it. (Time expired)
