TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up too much time of the House. I just wanted to make a couple of comments about this amendment before it was closed off. The point that I wanted to make again was that I think constitutionally the better way of handling these requested amendments, as they are in a sense technical adjustments of the original bill, was for the government to have reintroduced the bill in the House of Representatives and then again forwarded it on to the Senate. That was the better constitutional way to handle these matters to facilitate these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, I had to respond to the challenge of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) when he said, `The breadth of these amendments actually touches the families of Australia.' In effect, the amendment that we are dealing with deals with the taxable income that spouses receive from a trust estate or from the trust of a deceased estate. I freely confess to this House that I am completely unaware of the scope of this measure as it relates to my own electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. The member for Chifley is referring back to Senate amendment No. 1. We have dealt with Senate amendment No. 1. We are now dealing with Senate amendment No. 2.
—Order! The honourable member is addressing the matter before the chair.
—I quote from the amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . taxable income is taken to be the beneficiary's share of the net income of a trust estate in respect of which the trustee is liable to be assessed or to pay tax under section 98 of the Tax Assessment Act.

I think the problem for the honourable member for McPherson is that amendments 1 and 2 are related. The point I want to make to the honourable member for McPherson and to the House is that I suspect that in my electorate of Chifley—and I would have thought that no‐one would argue that there are many fine battlers living in the electorate of Chifley—

TALK.START.PARA: —And well represented.

—I thank the honourable member for Cunningham. He is an astute judge in these matters. I cannot say that I am aware of any of my constituents' spouses being such beneficiaries. I cannot think of one. In case I am making a false statement, I plead with any of my constituents who are listening this afternoon to ring me if they are a spouse who is a beneficiary of a trust or the estate of a trust.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to misrepresent the situation when I say that not one person in my electorate will benefit from these measures. In fact, they are not designed to benefit from these measures. It is not the poor or the middle class who will benefit from these amendments, it is those who are well practised in tax matters in setting up trusts. Trusts are set up with the single purpose of minimising taxable income.

I am not in favour of this amendment because it is not going to benefit any of my constituents. They are certainly not in the wealthy brigade who can spend thousands of dollars rearranging their tax affairs to pay a minimal amount of tax. It is a pity that the government did not follow the advice of the shadow minister, who suggested that we could have avoided these constitutional difficulties if the parliamentary secretary had been prepared to reintroduce the bill and then forward it to the Senate. (Time expired)
Amendment agreed to.
Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (1.29 p.m.)—I move:
That amendment No. 3 be agreed to.

This is also a minor technical amendment. It clarifies the operation of proposed subparagraph 20P(3)(b) to make it clear that the subparagraph is intended to apply to couples who separate after the end of the year of income. Without the amendment, the provision is ambiguous. We acknowledge that, and that is why the amendment is being moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is pleased to support this amendment to the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill. We note that the first two amendments were taking away eligibility for the family tax initiative, contrary to government election promises. This is an amendment which, as was outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), seeks to confer eligibility on parents who have separated.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of this provision, however, it is worth repeating that the opposition does not regard the Senate as having a legitimate authority or power to move an amendment; it should have come to us by way of a request. But now it is here, and now that it has been put by the parliamentary secretary, it is appropriate to raise the whole raft of administrative difficulties that the government has with the family tax initiative.

This is a provision that relates to parents when they separate. It is worth noting that the situation where two or more people jointly maintain a dependant and those people do not reside together was to be dealt with in the proposed section 20L of the bill, which provides that the child will only be considered to be a dependant for the days when the taxpayer has care of the child for the night.

I would have thought that, for members who are worried about privacy and the basic rights of citizens to privacy, this is a new infringement that the government is imposing upon the citizens of Australia in an attempt to force them to keep a logbook to determine for taxation purposes whether or not their dependent child stayed for the night. And not only that, the government is further breaching privacy by forcing parents to keep a logbook for the amount of time that they have dependent children within their care. The administrative efficiency of it is a total nightmare; the administrative arrangements are a total nightmare.

BREAK.PARA: Let me raise a hypothetical situation to illustrate what will happen. Say one parent starts out the PAYE period with 70 per cent of the care of the dependent child and the other parent, separated, 30 per cent. Because the government is paying this through PAYE deductions rather than through a rebate, if the 70/30 ratio changes at any time, the employer will have to be notified, and will subsequently have to change the PAYE deduction to reflect, say, a change to 50/50. Imagine the administrative nightmare and the inconvenience and the breach of privacy for people.

First of all, they have to keep a log as to how many nights the dependent child spent with them. These arrangements are always flexible and fluid. If the arrangements change and go from 70/30 to 50/50 they have to present a log to their employer to say that the child is now half in their care instead of 70 per cent; they have to ask the employer to alter the PAYE deduction for the purpose of the family tax initiative.

The government clearly had not thought any of these things through before it brought the family tax initiative legislation into the House. I note the concern that is echoed on the faces of the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) now that the penny has dropped. The penny has dropped that their much vaunted family tax initiative is an administrative nightmare. What you are setting up in the name of family values is a tax logbook on separated parents: when they have the care of a dependant in their house for the night—not for the day, necessarily, just for the night—they need to put it on the night log. If those arrangements change from PAYE period to PAYE period, they have to tell their employer of that and he will notify the Taxation Office through a change to the PAYE deduction.

That is an extraordinarily draconian provision for a government to impose. It is a nightmare for people in terms of their right to privacy. Why should employers know the arrangements that their employees have with regard to dependent children? Why should they have the right to know how many nights their separated employees have dependent children in their houses? Why do they have that right to know? Why, even, does the Taxation Office have that right to know? The answer is: because the government engaged in the folly of not paying this as a rebate or a cash transfer. They decided to pay it by virtue of their electoral research and by virtue of their focus group findings. They decided to pay it as a PAYE deduction. That has led to a whole series of administrative inefficiencies and privacy concerns that this parliament should note.

The member for McPherson looks as though he is about to jump to his feet. He is one of the executive members of the Lyons Forum. He is one of the creators of this family tax initiative. Let him explain to separated parents in Australia why they need to keep a taxation logbook every night they have a dependent child in their house. Let him explain why employers should have access to that information. Let him explain why the tax office should. This is worse than the Australia Card. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I might leave it to the parliamentary secretary to answer the question of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) in detail, but I was provoked and I just want to make a couple of brief comments. The family tax initiative is $1 billion for Australian families. The member for Werriwa once again demonstrates to this House his disingenuousness by 15 minutes ago calling divisions on a principle that there was something wrong with the way these amendments had been introduced. That is when he did not agree with the amendments, because they in fact did what he could hardly argue against, and that is ensure that these benefits were properly targeted. What he is trying to argue now is that somehow targeting is an issue. It has always been an issue for both houses of this parliament that we are concerned about benefits being properly targeted, and yet the argument that he now puts forward in some sense is that it should not be so. So the argument here is about the proper targeting of these benefits and that is why—
—What about the logbook?

—What about a logbook? The issue here, of course, is targeting and making sure that those that are entitled to and eligible for the benefits get them and making sure that if they are not entitled to them they do not. There are always going to be difficulties with ensuring that those benefits get through to those that are entitled to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me answer quickly the question about rebates. This is a tax rebate and the member for Werriwa was correct in suggesting it could be delivered at the end of the year, but the obvious point of that is that that would not give the maximum advantage. The point of doing it through the PAYE system is to make sure the families benefited from it immediately, so on the first payday after 1 January all of the families in Australia that are eligible for this $1 billion tax cut will get it in their tax packets. Is the member for Werriwa opposed to those families getting that benefit in their first pay packet after 1 January?

TALK.START.PARA: —If they apply, they do.

—If they are eligible then they will get it, and it is a matter of semantics arguing about whether they apply or not. The fact is that if they are eligible they will know they are eligible and they will get it. You are being disingenuous in the way that you are treating these amendments and by doing so you are demonstrating, in my view, a lack of commitment to Australian families.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP
SPEECH.PARA: That amendment No. 4 be agreed to.

This amendment enables but does not compel taxpayers to quote their spouses' tax file numbers in their tax returns. The quotation will be on a voluntary basis but the information gained will be useful to help prevent double dipping. Arrangements will be worked out to ensure that the consent of a spouse is sought before his or her tax file number is quoted. Without the amendment, it would be an offence for a taxpayer to ask his or her spouse for a spouse's tax file number and for the taxpayer to quote the tax file number to the commissioner.
I make the comment that, in terms of privacy, there is no privacy being infringed in regard to this; it is voluntary. I would just like to make that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear that it is voluntary. What do we do about a dispute? What do we do in a situation where both of the separated parents are claiming substantive care of the dependent child? They are both claiming, say, 80 or 90 per cent of the dependent care of the child. How does the tax office deal with that situation if we are not to have some form of record like a logbook? I would have thought what the parliamentary secretary has done to the taxation system is to encourage everyone to claim as much as they feel inclined to claim. If they want to claim 80 and 80, 160, why not? The government will pay 160 per cent benefit. Is that the case? If the government is to police this properly, certainly it needs to have some form of administrative system in place. I would be very surprised indeed if the parliamentary secretary's assurance holds that there will be no breach of privacy as that administrative system is put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: As he mentioned, this final amendment on the bill deals with the question of double dipping. So the nightmare of the family tax initiative and its administration gets worse. Not only are there the compliance costs for employers of constantly changing their PAYE deductions, not only is there the breach of privacy for separated parents as their employer and the tax office know the arrangements that they have struck in their private life—the nightmare on Lyons Street gets even worse. The nightmare on Lyons Street gets even worse because the Lyons Forum has now run into the problem of how to prevent double dipping. It probably is very difficult in these circumstances to prevent a situation where both parents will claim for the family tax initiative. This is a problem of a taxation system in Australia based on individual income yet the benefit being paid to family units.

PARA.BREAK: If both parents claim, what is the government going to do about it? What is the government going to do about double dipping other than this amendment here, the sole purpose of which is to beg people to volun teer the tax file number of their spouse as they lodge their application for the family tax initiative?

SPEECH.PARA: The government is begging people to do the right thing but people are not obliged to lodge the tax file number of their spouse as they themselves apply for the family tax initiative. This creates a very interesting situation as to what the Taxation Office will do to try to prevent double dipping. I would have thought it would generate a huge data matching exercise for the Taxation Office. The ATO will now have to match the data from spouse to spouse right across Australia. I know that the Lyons Forum is all about keeping people together in holy wedlock but they are going to be doing it through the tax office by matching people up against each other with their tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're splitting them up, are they?

—No, the Labor Party is not splitting them; we believe in choice. Remember that strange notion, that strange notion of small `l' liberalism upon which your party was founded? We believe in choice and liberty. We do not think people should be forced into living together if they choose other arrangements. They might be single or divorced, they are elements in our society. Choice!

SPEECH.PARA: We are not social engineers. We are not part of the big `C' conservative movement for authority in Australia. We are not part of an authoritarian strongarm movement that tells people that because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) grew up in a white picket fence family everyone else should, or because you grew up in a white picket fence family that everyone else should. We believe in choice and freedom in a free and open society.

That is the Australian Labor Party's position. What the Lyons Forum has created is social engineering. Members of the forum are trying to tell women that they belong in the home even though many women in Australia so joyfully choose both a career and a family—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why we've got so many women in parliament.
—We all know the sort of women the Liberal Party prefers. We are seeing that at the Opera House today. I would not talk too much about the rights of women and feminist issues in Australian politics.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue on the final amendment is one of double dipping. The government has created a nightmare for the Taxation Office. There are additional compliance costs on employers. So much for the recommendations of your small business report which was going to lower compliance costs on small business. Each small business in Australia will now have to alter PAYE tax deductions on a weekly or monthly basis because there has been a change in the household care of dependent children that then flows on to the family tax initiative. We not only have a breach of privacy, we have the problem of how the Taxation Office stops double dipping.

There is no compulsion on people to provide the tax file number of their spouse. That is only voluntary, and if people do not volunteer there will have to be a huge data matching exercise thereby adding to the costs of running Australia's taxation system. The Labor Party would much rather see those expenses devoted to the real task of tax policing in Australia, cracking down on fraud and cracking down on abuse at the big end of town.
The Labor Party would much rather see those scarce ATO resources dedicated to catching the tax cheats and the tax frauds. (Extension of time granted).

We know why the Liberal Party will not devote the resources where they are needed within the Taxation Office. They are trying to police the situation with their own flawed family tax initiative to stop double dipping when the sensible thing to do would be to allocate those resources to the real purpose of tax policing in Australia, to catch the big corporate crooks, the tax fraud at the big end of town. Instead, resources will be spent looking through the bedroom windows of Australians through the introduction of this logbook to see what arrangements they are making with their dependent children.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Braddon (Mr Miles) earned a reputation in this parliament for wanting the Tasmanian police to look through the bedroom windows of consenting adults on the question of the sex laws and, true to form, he now wants the Taxation Office to be looking through the bedroom windows of Australians to work out whether or not their dependent child is there, whether or not the logbook is correct and whether or not double dipping is taking place.

I would suggest that the government really should have accepted the Labor Party's proposal at the beginning of this debate to have a conference between the House and the Senate to look at the gross administrative inefficiencies of the family tax initiative and see how its administration is unravelling day after day after day. Do something positive about lowering compliance costs for small business. Do something positive about protecting the privacy of Australian citizens. Do something positive about an effective means to stop the potential for double dipping on the family tax initiative.

The government has rejected those things and it is to its lasting shame that it could not find a better way. It is the old message in public life: good policy stands on its own; good policy leads to sound administration. The government engaged in base electoral research to work out the way in which Australian families would want the family tax initiative paid. As Mr Howard offered his fistful of dollars, the researchers said, `Pay it through the tax system with PAYE deductions.' In terms of administration, that focus group was wrong, the Lyons Forum was wrong, and the government was wrong. I look forward to reinforcing those points in this House in the lead‐up to 1 January and for a long time thereafter.
Amendment agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Mr Prosser:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity in this debate on the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) and cognate bills to go to the issue of priority in terms of this government's listing of business. I note that, while I am addressing this, there is not one member of the government frontbench at the table. I seem to recall their making a point of that in relation to us earlier today. This is the government that was going to lift standards and make itself more accountable, and yet it has not even got the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) in the House, let alone anyone delegated for him.
—Like you used to do?

—There is the question of the priority that brings this bill to the House. We have to have a backbencher intervene to defend the non‐existent, absent frontbench. Half of them will be absent in question time. There will be no Prime Minister, no Deputy Prime Minister, no Minister for Foreign Affairs and no Minister for Primary Industries and Energy at question time today, and yet they say they are more accountable! The priority that brings this bill to the House is disturbing, as is the impact of the measure itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just go back to the events that occurred on Tuesday night to demonstrate yet again the way in which this government treats the procedures of this House with contempt. We had an agreement on Tuesday night in debating some very important tax measures: one that sees cuts to research and development expenditures in this country which will, in turn, see research and development go overseas; the other which increases taxes on cooperatives, including a cooperative in the parliamentary secretary's own electorate of Braddon. Yet he sat by and allowed that tax to be implemented.

We had an agreement: the opposition said that we would treat the bill as a whole and, therefore, not insist upon going through it clause by clause. We had an agreement that we would be able to move our four amendments, and that agreement was breached. It was breached because the government came into the place with the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) absent—celebrating his passage of resolution through the Senate of the IR bill. He was not even in the House to manage the agreement that he had entered into. The government would not let us move an amendment on cooperatives to support them, and we know that members of the National Party were prepared to cross the floor on it. The government would not allow us to move amendments that retained the 150 per cent tax concession and retained syndication.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. There are plenty of forums in the House where the leader can speak about these things. He has advantages others do not have, but I draw your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the matter of relevance: the subject under discussion is a customs bill, not what happened in the House last Tuesday.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G. H. Adams)

TALKER.NAME: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G. H. Adams)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call the honourable member's attention to the three bills that are concurrently before the House.

—I am addressing them, Mr Deputy Speaker, because what is important is the circumstance in which this particular bill comes here in the first place. It is true that I will have plenty of opportunities to raise the disgraceful procedures that you are implementing in this House. This is one of them and I will use it because of the way in which you proceeded on Tuesday night to deny us the ability to move amendments when it had been agreed that we should.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that we have here is the impact of the measures themselves. In all of the time that we have been debating it, we have not had the minister responsible for this particular measure in the House. The minister responsible for Customs is not in the House. I am pleased to say, though, that by the introduction of this particular bill, the minister has actually now declared that he has responsibility for something. I was beginning to believe that he was getting his ministerial salary under false pretences because every time we said he was responsible for something, to demonstrate his conflict of interest, he said, `No, I'm not responsible for that.'

To give some examples: when we pointed out the minister's conflict of interest between his construction company, a private company that he still holds a directorship of and a substantial number of shares in, and his ministerial responsibility, his defence was that he was not responsible for construction. His words were memorable. I remind members of the House that he said, `I've built a business. I've been out there in the heat and the dust working in the rain and the cold.'

Mr Deputy Speaker, there was not a dry eye in the place when he told us that. But, unfortunately, having said he was not responsible for construction, he forgot to tell his department, because they went over to the Senate and, in the Senate estimates committee, said he was responsible for the building code. But next, when we pointed to the conflict of interest between his involvement—

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order—
—Oh, here he is. You do not like this, do you—the conflict of interest, the denial by the minister? He is not here to defend himself, so he has to rely on this thug.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Chief Government Whip has a point of order.

—I have drawn your attention to this matter once, Mr Deputy Speaker. I expect you to have the member comply with the matter before the House: the three Customs bills. He should confine his remarks to those three bills and not to any other matter.

—The shadow minister and leader of opposition business was speaking to the Customs bill and about the minister's responsibilities. I think that that goes to the three bills that are concurrently before the House.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order. I take offence at the last comment made by the member for Hotham about the member for Mitchell. He referred to him as a thug and I ask that he withdraw it.
—I did not hear the comment. I will leave it up to the honourable member.
—I thought the person concerned had to be offended. I believe he is not offended; he likes the title. So I do not withdraw in those circumstances—unless the member asks me to withdraw.
—No, I am offended by that.
—You can be offended. Offended by what is said about him?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am asking him to withdraw those comments.
—I leave it up to the honourable member.

—I withdraw the statement. I just note that the person concerned was not offended. I was addressing the question of the minister's responsibilities, or lack of them, because it is relevant to this debate on Cus toms and the responsibilities which he is pursuing, as well as the stated aims when he took over this portfolio as to what he was going to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned one of the things that he said he is not responsible for when he was caught up with conflict of interest. I mention another. On a previous occasion I pointed to his involvement in petrol retailing, again through his private company, again through his directorship of it, at the same time advocating policy measures that would put money back into the pockets of petrol retailers. When we pointed this out to him, he said he was not responsible for that either. Even though he was minister for consumer affairs, he was not responsible for petrol retailing. He was acting for some other minister in the circumstances.

One could say that is a reasonable defence, but it is not what he was saying before the meeting or after it. He went to the meeting. The question of the temperature control of petrol was on the agenda of the Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs meeting. It was the reason he issued a press release on the matter under his title as minister for consumer affairs, and those press statements discussed the impact of the measure on consumers. Though he saw no need at the meeting itself to declare that he was representing another minister, it was his defence in this House when he got nailed. So I am pleased to say that we have got a minister who is responsible for doing something in his portfolio, because he has denied any involvement in other activities that we have nailed him on previously.

Let me also go to the question of his responsibility for the diesel fuel rebate. The minister, through his directorship and control of Prosser Automotive Engineers Pty Ltd, does deal in diesel fuel and he has got responsibility for administering the act that sets the rates and conditions under which the diesel fuel rebate can be obtained. Yet, when this conflict of interest was pointed out, he said there was no conflict of interest here either because his companies are not eligible to claim the diesel fuel rebate. This is hardly the point. While diesel users claim the rebate, those who deal in diesel benefit from the rebate's retention, and that is still an issue on which the minister has not been prepared to address this House or his Prime Minister.

I see he has finally turned up in the House. He was not here to defend his bill. He has never defended himself, except for the blood and the toil and the teary‐eyed speech, and he still will not come into this place and explain the blatant conflicts of interest inherent in his continued activities: diesel fuel rebate, construction, consumer affairs—you name them.

As I said before, what is really involved in this is not the issue of whether there is evidence that the minister has deliberately sought to profit; it is the question of the appearance of the conflict of interest. The appearance occurs over and over again with this minister. So it is pleasing to find today that the minister is responsible for something, because he has been denying all along that he is responsible for the things that he has got caught on. I thought that you were obtaining your money under false pretences, Minister, because every time we identified issues that you are in conflict with, you said, `No, I'm not responsible for that. No, I don't deal with that.'

I am pleased to see that he has actually got responsibility for something, and it has to deal with the Customs Service. I am sure that people who work in the Customs Service would have hoped that he ducked this issue too, because, when you look at the issues that he has involved himself in there—a $70 million cut over the next four years to the service, 105 jobs gone in Victoria, 65 in New South Wales, 60 in the ACT, 25 in Queensland, 20 in Western Australia, and the complete ending of airport shiftwork—they would wish he had not been involved in this either.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, do you recall saying on AM this morning, in seeking to defend the Prime Minister's failure and your own failure on the latest private health insurance premium increases, `They have come in, both of them, with lower than would have happened otherwise'? Is the minister aware of the first paragraph of an MBF press release which states, `A notification of contribution rates as originally submitted by MBF has been approved by the federal government'? Minister, doesn't this show that you and the Prime Minister did nothing more than delay the announcement of these increases so that you could hide behind the visit of President Clinton? Who is telling the truth, Minister—you or MBF?

—No, I am not aware of MBF's press release. What I would say is that there were several submissions and I am not sure to which one they are referring, but the original submission that they would have made back in October was quite different from what was granted. —Mr Speaker, my question is also addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services.
