ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He obviously has hit the point right on the head because the fact is that what we are experiencing now is the result of what the funds experienced over the 1995‐96 financial year. Funds right across Australia had a pretty tough time then, and they are having a tough time now because the make‐up of their membership base is changing. People who are over 65 are making up a greater proportion of people who have private health insurance. I say 65 because that is the age at which people generally draw more than a dollar having put a dollar in.

ANSWER.PARA: This is in fact something that has happened progressively over a number of years. The trouble that the Labor Party has is that they basically do not like private health insurance. This was put very well in August by the former health minister, Graham Richardson, who said this:

I steered a package through the cabinet but resigned before I could sell it to the caucus. Practically the whole package died when I left the Labor Party because the Labor Party has always been a bit biased against private health insurance.
In fact, you only have to look at their record. We hear the Labor Party bleating about premium increases, but between 1986 and 1988 they went up 40 per cent.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do about it? Nothing. You sat on your hands and you rubber‐stamped every premium increase. And then, between 1991 and 1992, in the financial year, they went up by 17 per cent. So what you did was you hit the old, you hit the frail, you hit the 700,000 people who had incomes under $20,000 a year who still were clinging on to their private health insurance. And you did it because you are a bit biased against private health insurance. It was purely ideologically driven.

ANSWER.PARA: And how did you do it? You did it very simply. You abolished the federal government's contribution to the reinsurance bill between 1983 and 1989, and you whacked $100 million onto the cost of premiums of private health insurance.

You reduced the Commonwealth bed‐day subsidy in September 1986 and you whacked another $135 million onto the cost of private health insurance. You then reduced the Medicare rebate for in‐hospital services from 85 per cent to 75 per cent and you whacked that onto private health insurance premiums. According to Access Economics, that added, in today's dollars, $846 million onto the cost of private health insurance premiums. That means premiums today are 39 per cent higher than they would have been had you not taken those decisions. Now we see the crocodile tears, we hear the bleating, we hear the gnashing of the teeth, the tearing at the heartstrings, but basically you have always been a bit biased against private health insurance.

With respect to these recent increases, yesterday Medibank Private and MBF announced that there would be premium increases. I approved the increase for MBF on Tuesday. I approved the increase for Medibank Private on Wednesday. When I say `approved', I said that I had no grounds to disallow them. The fact is that, even if you look at those two premium increases, if you average all premiums over recent times, the average increase is a little bit more than six per cent. That is no different from the average increase between March and August. That compares to 12 per cent per year average that you let go through. If you have a look at between 1983 and 1996, you will see that the Labor ministers for health never once intervened. You gave it the tick, you gave it the rubber stamp and you let a 40 per cent increase in two years between 1986 and 1988 go through.

I would prefer that there were no increases at all. At least with these two premium increases, I have been able to intervene. I have asked Medibank Private and MBF to go back and re‐work their figures. I have asked them to look at their assumptions again, and they did. Not only have the premium increases that have come in been less than what they would have been otherwise—something you never did because you are a bit biased against private health insurance—but also they have been deferred, and that is good news for private health insurance. It is good news for the contributors. At least I am having a go. You never had the guts to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good news is it, Michael? It's good new, is it? My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Does the minister stand by his claim this morning on the AM program that `the average increase for MBF is 6.5 per cent'? Does this not assume that 300,000 MBF contributors will downgrade their existing cover? Is it not the case that currently 75 per cent of MBF contributors have no excess cover and will face a 15 per cent increase? Minister, if you claim that you are concerned about low income earners who are paying for private health insurance, are you concerned about the pensioners and the families who are MBF contributors who cannot afford to downgrade and cannot afford to take the risk of a significant excess when they get sick? Is it not a fact that these people will have to pay that extra 15 per cent increase in their premiums as a result of your decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been handed a copy of this MBF press release that the shadow minister is happy to quote from. It states, `a rise in contribution rates of 6.5 per cent across the fund's memberships overall'. So MBF seems to think that it is 6.5 per cent as well.
—Read the whole quote; don't be selective!
—Order! The member for Dobell.
—I make no apology whatsoever for opening up a greater range of products to fund members. I make no apology at all.

ANSWER.PARA: When I became minister, the funds were rigid and had very little flexibility. That provided the public no choice. I have made a deliberate decision to try and offer a greater flexibility of products—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the minister was asked whether he stands by that figure of 6.5 per cent. He is getting away from that specific question.
—There is no point of order. The minister is traversing a wide topic.

—The last two‐yearly TQA health survey on private health insurance, released in late 1995, shows that there is substantial opportunity with front‐end deductible products. People want them. There is an opportunity there for new entrants, who have not been there before, to come into the market. I am going to actively encourage it. It has moved quite quickly in recent years: the number of people with front‐end deductible products has gone from about five per cent of contributors to about 25 per cent. There is absolutely no reason to think that this should not continue.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the benefits Australian families are now receiving as a direct result of the government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When the coalition went to the last election, it went to it promising Australian families that it would stand by them. The coalition promised them that it would recognise, through the tax system, the cost of rearing children.
—A bit of emphasis, Peter. Put more oomph into it. Use your hands a bit.
—The member for Melbourne is not playing cricket!
—And that it would cut Australian families back into the tax system in a way in which they had been forgotten under 13 years of Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: The proudest boast that this government can make is that legislation today passed the House to deliver on that fundamental commitment to Australian families. As a result of this government's legislative program and as a result of the budget that we brought down, on 1 January next year all Australian families who qualify under the family tax initiative are going to get a recognition of the cost of raising children and are going to be cut into the Australian tax system in a new way. This is a new deal for a new year for new Australian families from a new government with a new start.
As a result, in relation to each child, there will be an increase of $1,000 in the tax‐free threshold for qualifying families earning up to $70,000

TALK.START.PARA: —Now point the finger, Peter.
—The member for Melbourne!

—For single income families an increase of $2,500 in the tax‐free threshold where at least one child is under the age of five years. For a qualifying family with two children, one under five, that means that their tax will be reduced by $34.60 a fortnight from 1 January next year. This underlines and demonstrates the coalition's commitment to Australia's families—the kinds of families that returned the member for Lindsay in increasing droves in the recent by-election, the kinds of families which have deserted the Labor Party after having been deserted by the Labor Party over 13 years.

ANSWER.PARA: Low income families will also have the alternative of fortnightly cash assistance called the fortnightly tax payment. One of the things that makes this government proud about this new deal for Australian families is the way in which it delivers benefits right across the spectrum, especially to those on low incomes.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.

—This is a change to the tax system which, in tax dollars, is worth exactly the same to the low income earner as it does to the qualifying middle income earner. It is a proud day for this government to be able to deliver on its family tax initiative. We know that the 1993 tax promise of the Labor Party, the l-a-w tax cuts, has never been delivered till this day.
—Come on, Peter; some more hand movements.
—I warn the member for Melbourne.
—Yet this government can stand up and say proudly shortly after its election to office, `We have delivered on time, in full, to Australia's families.'

—My question directed to the Treasurer relates to the 15 per cent increase in premiums that were previously discussed. Treasurer, the Minister for Health and Family Services claimed this morning that these massive private health insurance pre mium increases had to be approved before the Productivity Commission reports in February—everything was supposed to be held off until then—because, to quote the minister, `We can't let the funds go broke.' Isn't it the case that at least one of the funds which had approved increases of up to 15 per cent had reserves which were almost twice the minimum level when these increases were approved? Given your central role in this process, can you explain your approval for these massive premium increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Health and Family Services has indicated, he has looked at the required criteria and, in conjunction with the Prime Minister and me, determined that the increases, as he negotiated, were approved. In relation to prudential requirements, the government of course always has an eye for prudential requirements and makes sure that they are justly taken into account—and they were.

ANSWER.PARA: But let me say in relation to the comments the minister for health has already made, what strategy did Labor ever have to reverse declining private health insurance? Nothing. It not only presided over the decline of it but had no strategy to reverse it. As a result, there was no change whatsoever that could have delivered any behavioural response in relation to private health insurance. So how ill does it fit in your mouth to now complain about fees?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise to take a point of order which goes to relevance. It was a very clear‐cut question related specifically to the point about the inclusion or otherwise in his consideration as to whether or not there were adequate funds in the reserves of the health companies which received approval. It was a specific question with no generality associated to it at all. Therefore, what he is saying now must surely be irrelevant to it.
—I thank the Leader of the Opposition. The Treasurer is using some wide-ranging examples before he focuses on the specifics.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Of course, I have addressed the prudential requirements which were taken into account by the minister for health and detailed to the Prime Minister and me. But the real point is this: what strategy did Labor have to try to stem the decline or turn it around? Nothing. Thirteen years of nothing. No movement. In comes a coalition government and as matter of priority it sits down and says, `Let's put the incentive in place to reverse the decline.'

ANSWER.PARA: Not only did this coalition government give incentives to low income earners; this coalition government had the guts to do something that Labor never would: in the budget it gave an incentive for the high income earner to take out private health insurance. We also know, by the way, that the Labor Party would have liked to have done it but, because Paul Keating refused to take out private health insurance, your whole government was stymied on the issue.

So how ill does it fit in your mouths to be complaining about premium increases? If Labor had been in government, the premiums increases would have continued with no offsetting government response. Now we have an offsetting government response to stem the decline, to turn it around. This is the response which was required by leadership, and that is why we undertook it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the next question, I advise members that we have in the gallery this afternoon Dr Lenoid Kravchuk, the former President of the Ukraine, and a small delegation. We welcome you to Australia, sir. May you enjoy your visit with us.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of comments reported today in the Australian Financial Review that the government's changes to the functions of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission have altered the focus of that tribunal for the better? Can the minister confirm for the benefit of the House the substance of Justice Kirby's observations on the government's new industrial relations scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. Some very interesting remarks from Mr Justice Kirby are reported in the Australian Financial Review . On the basis of that report, I believe he is correct in his observations that under the government's reforms the commission has a crucial role to play in protecting vulnerable workers. Whilst the commission's role will be different, its status and involvement will certainly be integral to the effective functioning of the new system. I am very pleased to be able to join with the Treasurer today as he announces the passage of the legislation which gives people a big tax cut from 1 January.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also pleased to say that this morning the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill went through the lower house, completed its passage in the parliament, to give Australia a new industrial relations system from 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, a great New Year's Day.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: REITH

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a great New Year's Day, as the Treasurer says. It means that we have modernised the role of the commission and in some respects its role will be enhanced.

INTERJECT.PARA: For example, in relation to the unfair dismissal law, applications will go to the commission. Its dispute settlement role will be emphasised. Its role in the maintenance of the award safety net is to be reinforced. It has an important job there. In respect of certified agreements, it will also administer the no disadvantage test. It will assess proposed Australian workplace agreements referred from the Employment Advocate where approval against the no disadvantage test is considered to be doubtful.

It will also have a continuing role to make orders to ensure equal remuneration. It will prepare a report on junior wage rates, which will be very important in the debate about junior wage rates. It will handle revised arrangements for assessing proposals for federal award coverage, the registration of new unions and altered coverage of existing unions. It will also supervise the award simplification process, which is very important. What that really means is that, in a practical legislative sense, our policy now is there for all to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this your pitch for Foreign Minister?
—The honourable member for Banks!

—We are going forward and implementing that policy. While the focus has been on the government's package, no‐one should let escape the fact that, whilst we were putting down our policy for industrial relations, the Labor Party was having its policy dictated to it by the ACTU as it was putting down it policy.

ANSWER.PARA: What we now know—and it may seem a long way off but it should not be forgotten—is that, when we get to the next election, the only party that can upset the continuing implementation of the genuine reform that we have commenced, the only party that can put an alternative, is the Labor Party. I will tell you what their alternative is, because they have been moving these amendments. Their alternative policy for the next election is to scrap sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act to give their mates in the trade union movement a privileged position. You won't believe it, but their policy now is also to bring back Laurie Brereton's unfair dismissal law. It makes you the laughing stock of Australian politics for this to be your position. You have moved those amendments in the upper house.

You are opposed to award simplification, so that means you want awards to be more prescriptive than ever. You want to tie up business with red tape in a way they have never been tied before and from which we are unshackling them in this legislation. You want to put a cap on damages for your mates in the trade union movement—another classic immunity for your mates in the trade union movement. You would destroy the jobs of young people by abolishing junior wage rates. Finally, we were fascinated that, at the behest of your trade union mates, in the Senate you opposed our disamalgamation provisions—that I can understand—and you then opposed altogether any prospect of disamalgamation for any unionists. That can only mean, of course, that if you are ever re‐elected you would give the green light again to the super union process which has been a complete failure for rank and file trade unionists.
This act says a lot about our policy but it also gives people a very clear idea of Labor's industrial relations policy. We will be very happy to remind you of it all the way to the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts inform the House why telecommunications carriers can build towers and roll out cable just about wherever they want to, often against the wishes of the local communities affected?
—I am pleased to try to answer the member's question. This matter is a long, detailed and complex issue.
—It sounds like you cannot do it.

—No, I do understand it. One person in this House who can understand it would be me, Mr Crean. It is a genuine question and it concerns many people in this House. The point that must be made is that in 1991 a code was put in place to deal with these issues of the roll‐out of the relevant networks. That code was championed by the present Leader of the Opposition when he was minister for communications. How quickly we forget, but you were the one.
—Oh, him?

—Yes, this fellow. That code was put in place by your government and that code has been found wanting. That code is now being reassessed by the government. Senator Alston, the minister for communications, is in detailed discussions with the Australian Local Government Association, the backbench committee and the cabinet to put in place a meaningful code to ensure we get the benefits of enhancing competition in telecommunications, to ensure we get a reduction in prices for the benefit of consumers, at the same time taking account of the concerns of local communities about the aesthetics of cable roll‐out and so on.

BREAK.PARA: I can assure the Independent member for Moore that this government will take seriously the responsibilities that it has to ensure that we come up with a code that will cater for the concerns of all members of this House, particularly those government members who expressed concerns about this matter. We expect Senator Alston to announce shortly some changes to the new national code which will take account of those concerns and will remedy the deficit which we were left with in the code given to us by the Labor opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Yesterday, the Treasurer announced that the Commonwealth, Victoria and the Bass Strait gas producers had entered into an agreement which will resolve the long running dispute over the liability for petroleum resource rent tax on Bass Strait gas production. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the prospective benefits for consumers resulting from this agreement?
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This is reviving debate on a matter before the House.
—It has been dealt with, I think. I call the Treasurer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate on behalf of the Commonwealth—
—What is your ruling?
—There is no point of order. I have called the Treasurer.

—I indicate on behalf of the Commonwealth that the settlement of the long running dispute over liability for petroleum resource rent tax on Bass Strait gas production between Victoria, the gas utilities and their suppliers is a great milestone in relation to a long running dispute which has held up much needed reform in the gas industry in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The resolution of the dispute has major economic benefits. The Financial Review today said `What a gas! Everyone wins!' I indicate that this outcome was negotiated between me and the Victorian Treasurer in relation to the tax aspects over the last two weeks in relation to intensive negotiations. I would like to thank him, as he has thanked me, for the way in which our teams of officials worked together to resolve this dispute under very difficult circumstances.

The essence of the dispute was over the imposition of the resource rent tax. The outcome of the dispute is that approximately $1 billion will be paid to the producers, producing about $620 million in windfall tax to the Commonwealth, $550 million of which will be passed back to the state of Victoria.

That is not the only part of the settlement. That pass back required an appropriation which the opposition cooperated in passing through the parliament this morning. I thank them for their contribution and I thank them for the cooperation that they showed in relation to that.

However, the good thing about this is that it now opens the way for more competition in the gas industry, for new pipelines to be built, for other regulatory barriers to be removed, to join a single market between New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Queensland, and to have the ending of monopoly arrangements where one supplier and one producer had monopoly in a particular area.

Hotter competition and more choice will make sure that there are opportunities for consumers, both domestic and industrial, to get cheaper gas. This will help our international competitiveness. This will mean that it will give benefits to Australian business and Australian producers and it will give opportunities to the businesses that rely on gas for their energy supplies to reduce costs. This is a win‐win‐win situation—win for Victoria, win for Esso‐BHP, win for the Commonwealth but, most of all, a win for business and a win for consumers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I remind you again of your statement on the AM program, when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: The average increase for MBF is 6.5 per cent.

I also remind you of your quote from the MBF press release in which you claimed that it said that the rise in contribution rates was 6.5 per cent across the fund's membership overall. Minister, do you agree that the full quote from the MBF press release is as follows:

. . . the anticipated effect of the changes, with the expected movement of members into and up the excess packages, is a rise in contribution rates of 6.5 per cent across the Fund's membership overall.

Minister, will you now concede that you have misled the listeners of the AM program and misled this House because you have assumed that 300,000 contributors will take up excess packages? Will you now concede that 75 per cent of MBF's contributors who do not have excess packages will face 15 per cent increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have assumed nothing. I have just assumed what MBF have assumed. They are the ones that have made the assumption. What the Labor Party cannot cope with is that the press release also says that in many cases people will have the cost of their cover reduced. The cost of people's cover may actually go down. That is because we have actively encouraged a range of new products.
—You have selectively quoted and you have misled the House.
—Order! The member for Dobell has asked his question.

—We have allowed greater flexibility in products to give people greater choice because we do not have the hang‐ups that you have with private health insurance. And this is good news for the Australian public.

ANSWER.PARA: The real hypocrisy of all of this, the gross hypocrisy of all of this, is that you sat on your hands for 13 years and did nothing. You sat on your hands for 13 years and whacked costs onto private health insurance premiums. You made the premiums 39 per cent higher than they needed to be. You did not in any way modify a single application in 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have misled the House.

—I have at least gone in there and tried to get a better deal for Australian fund contributors. The increase across all funds in the last few months has been an average of six per cent—March to April, it was six per cent. You had an average of 12 per cent a year when you were in office and nothing will hide your failure, nothing will hide your inactivity, and you will wear it day after day.

—Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. I note the minister's claim that he has made no assumptions—and that is on the record, thank you. I ask the minister: will he now concede that 75 per cent of MBF's contributors—those poor families that you mentioned before—who don't have excess packages will face increases of 15 per cent?
—I will allow the supplementary question.
—Oh, no. Mr Speaker, on a point of order: that should not be allowed. It is not elucidating an answer; it is simply repeating the question. On that basis, it should be ruled out of order.
—I have listened to the point of order. There is no point of order. I invite the Minister for Health and Family Services to add to his answer.
—Off the top of my head, I don't know whether that figure is right but I probably should have checked it—
—Well, why didn't you check?
—You should have.

—Because the shadow minister was using it this morning and, if it is as shonky as a lot of the other figures he uses, it is probably wrong. The fact is that the average increase will be as MBF said. I have read it across out of their press release.
—But you should know. You approved it.
—Order! The member for Dobell has had two bites of the cherry.

—If some people have the opportunity through new products to actually have lower premiums that is good news. But, yes, I do admit I cannot tell you off the top of my head what the membership structure of one of Australia's 47 health funds is—
—So you don't know. Is this the detailed consideration you gave it?
—Quite frankly, you probably didn't even know health funds existed until nine months ago.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Has the minister seen reports concerning army support for remote communities which suggest that the army will be involved in widespread construction projects in remote Aboriginal communities? Can the minister inform the House whether these reports are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Parkes for his question. There have been a number of media reports which have suggested the army will be conducting widespread construction tasks in some remote Aboriginal communities. I just wanted to clear this matter up because these reports are not entirely accurate and require clarification.

ANSWER.PARA: The ATSIC army community assistance project developed from a meeting between the Prime Minister and the members of the ATSIC council on 23 October this year. It was announced by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on 15 November. This project is designed to enhance ATSIC capabilities to improve water and related health infrastructure, and honourable members opposite should be interested in that.

Discussions are under way with ATSIC to identify tasks where the assistance can be best utilised. I want to emphasise that it is the army's role to involve itself in design project management and participate in projects on the ground in a small number of the most needy communities. In other words, its role is to involve itself in the management design of a pilot project to get the show on the road.

So the aim is to establish models for future projects that would involve civilian contractors and local communities down the track. The army will cover its own salary costs and the project costs will be met by ATSIC and by Health. The benefits to army will obviously lie in the training experience that will be gained, and the priority needs to be identified by ATSIC, and the benefits to the community speak for themselves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: New South Wales Public Hospital Funding

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister confirm that the federal government intends to slash $1 million a week out of New South Wales public hospital funding? Did the minister promise in his health policy not to cut public hospitals to pay for the failed private health insurance incentives? Is the minister concerned that Dr John Yu, the Australian of the Year, has criticised the government's policy as an attack on battlers? Can the minister also explain the timing of the announcement? Is the minister asking the Australian people to believe that it was just coincidental that the announcement was made following the Lindsay by-election and on the same day as President Clinton's visit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not $1 million a week. The figures are wrong. It is over a whole financial year. For New South Wales, it is $34 million which, quite honestly, is about $1 in $4 of what we would be entitled to take if we were taking back the cost shifting.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a problem here. I do not like having to do it, but there is one reason I have to do it. While successive Labor ministers bleated and wrung their hands and said how terrible cost shifting was, they did nothing about it. It has been left to me in this area, as well as to so many others, to fix up your mess. As to the timing, the announcement was made on 20 August in the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of comments about the difficulties employers experience taking on apprentices under Labor's complex and bureaucratic training system? Can the minister outline to the House what action the government is taking to improve the system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Leichhardt for his question. He is a member who has been very concerned about disadvantaged young people in his electorate and has spoken to me on many occasions about them. It is, therefore, entirely understandable that he is interested in the new initiatives of the government to increase opportunities for young people to train for real jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, as a result of the training policies that were put in place by the previous government, employers have been faced over the last 13 years with very substantial bureaucratic hurdles when they have wanted to employ an apprentice or a trainee. The fact that their policies have been dictated largely by the ACTU has meant that many small and medium sized businesses have been very hesitant to take on trainees because they do not want to invite a trade union into a previously non-unionised workplace.

The government is committed to greatly simplifying the training system and opening opportunities for young people. One of the important initiatives in this regard is going to be the introduction of one‐stop apprenticeship shops, which will streamline the process for employers of hiring an apprentice or a trainee and ensure that employers have ready access to our new flexible and simplified national training arrangements.

These one‐stop apprenticeship shops will have under one roof a number of services currently offered by a range of agencies both Commonwealth and state. They will provide a streamlined service in relation to both state and Commonwealth training regulations. They will also help businesses to process new flexible training arrangements and establish accredited on-the-job training and quality off-the-job training.

I have no doubt that one of the reasons why the member for Leichhardt has asked me this question is that Australia's first one‐stop apprenticeship shop will be established shortly in his electorate in Cairns. It is an unprecedented agreement between the federal government and the Queensland government to establish three of these one‐stop shops over the next few months. The Cairns pilot will be a partnership between the CES and the Queensland department of training. It will be sponsored by the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry and it will have a board of management comprising industry and government representatives.

The federal government is also negotiating with other state and territory governments to establish further one‐stop apprenticeship shops throughout Australia. The significance of this is that the government has once again delivered on the promise it made during the election campaign to provide training for young people which leads on to real jobs and to ensure that the training arrangements in this country are not those dictated by the ACTU but are those which meet the needs of business, large and small, for training which leads on to greater productivity, greater profitability and more jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen today's company profits figures from the ABS which show that, following a very sharp decline in the June quarter, trend profits were down again by 1.3 per cent in September and were down by 2.3 per cent compared with the same time last year? Has the Treasurer also seen the Westpac leading index of economic activity and the coincident index, both of which were released yesterday, both of which are significantly down for September and which together point to a very pessimistic outlook for activity at least until the middle of next year? Given this kind of evidence now emerging day after day after day, will the Treasurer now concede that it is not the opposition talking the economy down but government policy driving it down?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answers to the question are yes, yes, no. But in relation to the speech that was given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I would like to say a few things. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was obviously floundering and is, obviously, as I have said, not in command of any economic policy on behalf of the opposition. He gets up here and regularly gives us a little economic commentary on figures.

ANSWER.PARA: Like his economic commentary which said that our policy could never bring down credit card rates, four days before it did. Like his commentary when he came in here saying that the monthly unemployment figures would wipe the smile off the face of the government, when jobs increased by 25,000. Like the statement when he came in here and said that consumer confidence was flat, when it leapt eight points off the back of a half a point cut in official interest rates. Whatever he says is going down is going up. Whatever he says is going up is going down. His head is spinning until he comes to a dead end.

In relation to the company profits, the fact is that company profits rose by 0.3 per cent in the September quarter. They rose. It is true that there was a big decline in the June quarter, but that was before any measures on any basis that the government had put in place could have taken any effect. In relation to the measures we have put in place, of course cuts in official interest rates will kick in next year.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —When would you like the cuts in official interest rates to kick in? Before they were made? Was that your idea? Was it your idea that they should cut in before they were made? If they were made in July and November, they should have cut in by June? The fact is that you cut official interest rates, and they kick in subsequent to the cut. These cuts will kick in in 1997.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I said in the House the other day that one of the problems in the small business sector has been in relation to the house building industry. The opposition had a supply problem grow over the last couple of years, where supply was outstripping demand by a very large percentage. We expect the supply and demand to be coming back more into equivalence, and we expect a pick up in 1997.

We are putting in place changes in relation to interest rates. We have put in place changes in relation to capital gains tax. We are putting in place changes in relation to the provisional tax uplift factor. We are putting in place changes in relation to family tax incentives.

All we hear from the opposition, as the Minister for Industrial Relations said, is a position from right back when they were in the unreconstructed days of Breretonism in relation to industrial relations, from the unreconstructed days of Creanism, and from the doubly unreconstructed days of Fergusonism. That was back in the dinosaur age. When we had our friends in the gallery before, I thought we could have sent the opposition around to talk to them about perestroika. That might have made some difference in relation to your attitude on industrial relations.

It is important that we put in place the measures that are going to turn things around. Of course the biggest thing in relation to the budget was to turn around the legacy of deficit and debt. There is only one way to grow this economy on a sustained basis—that is, by addressing the two failures of Labor that gave us speed limits in relation to the current account deficit and in relation to inflation.

They are the measures that you in opposition are opposing. I do not know whether it has dawned on you yet, but you are opposing the measures that can put the Australian economy onto a path of sustainable growth. You, the Labor Party, are opposing them. The shadow Treasurer said, `Well, our policy would actually be to balance the budget over three years,' which is what the budget did. And he said it the day after the budget.

All I can say in relation to the economic position of the opposition is that, where there is no understanding, there is no conscience. Because opposition members do not understand what their position is, they get up and make these little statements which are taking them nowhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. Rising out of the Treasurer's reference to his triumph on credit cards earlier in the week, is he aware that, of the 157 cards offered by banks and financial institutions, only three as of Tuesday had dropped their interest rates by the full one per cent? Is he aware that less than one in five banks and financial institutions have passed on any rate cut at all?
—This question is outside the terms of the original question. The question is out of order.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware of the substantial interest in my electorate and other regions across Australia in the Australian meat and livestock `Reform for the future' task force report? What further consultations will be held on this task force report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Richmond for the question and also note his interest in the subject. On coming to government, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy put some priority action into our structure of the meat industry in Australia. One of the ways we can measure this great meat industry in Australia is by the value of exports from this nation. Beef and sheep meats annually contribute over $2.8 billion of export wealth to this country. The meat industry is also a substantial employer in regional Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not only a great wealth creator for regional Australia, but also a great wealth creator for this nation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on coming into government, said that he wanted to ensure that the meat industry in Australia was put on the best possible footing to cope with the challenges that lie ahead in the 21st century.

That report has been brought forward to the minister, on 31 October this year, and he has given a commitment to the meat industry to consult widely across Australia with the participants in the meat industry. He will be assisted by the member for Dawson, who not only has a great interest in the meat industry but also has a very long involvement in the meat industry as a producer in her own right along with her husband. Quite obviously, members on the other side have very little to do with and very, very little understanding of the meat industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know you are a meat head!
—I warn the member for Banks.

—And that is demonstrated by the rejection of you by people in regional Australia at the last election. The minister will commence those consultations at the end of this month and into December. As I said, he will be assisted by the member for Dawson in those consultations around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: On the completion of that consultation, the minister will bring a report forward to the cabinet with his recommendations. The reforms in the structure of the meat industry, coupled with the industrial relations reforms which were passed through this House, will set the meat industry in Australia on the path to meet and make the most of the opportunities that present themselves in the 21st century.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Following the information provided to the Senate by the Assistant Treasurer concerning the Finance Minister's unpaid loan from Lochreagh P/L, I ask: why did the minister fail to declare this outstanding loan in his pecuniary interest return both to the parliament and to the Prime Minister? Further, if for well over four years the minister made no attempt to repay the loan, shouldn't this money have been declared as income under section 108 of the tax act? How does the minister explain to the ordinary battling taxpayer how he received a substantial amount of money without paying it back or paying tax on it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When it comes to questions Nos 9 and 10 or so from the opposition, Mr Speaker, you know the opposition will run back to shares every single day. So devoid of issues are they, so much difficulty and trouble are they in, that they have to come back to the distractions because they have absolutely nothing else to contribute to the debate in this parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: I can indicate that the assumption the member makes about a substantial amount of money is, I assure you, not right. The only interest that particular company has is in a house property. It is a fibro cottage. It is occupied by my parents, who are both in their 80s, and it is paid for by myself and my sister each single month. The company has no revenue, and I am advised by my accountant that there is no tax implication.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame! Shame!
—Members on my right! Order! Resume your seats!

—Mr Speaker, my supplementary question is this: why then did Senator Kemp earlier this week in the Senate say there had been a loan to the directors which is unpaid? How much was the loan for? Will you repay the loan or pay tax on it?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is in order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Latham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You have asked your question.
—The Assistant Treasurer did indicate to the Senate that there was a loan to myself and my wife and that it is being repaid in a normal manner.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister inform the House how the government is addressing the longstanding shortage of medical specialists, especially surgeons, in rural Australia in places like Murray?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. As well as a shortage of general practitioners in rural areas, we face a shortage of specialists. If one looks at—
—I don't think it will do your career any good, Mark!
—I think we will wait until we read the papers tomorrow before we worry about anyone's career.
—Order! There is too much noise in the chamber. The member for Denison, I will not call you again.

—If one looks at the age structure of the surgical work force, it would appear that things are actually going to get worse before they get better, given that many of the surgeons in rural areas are old and approaching retirement certainly in the next 10 years. This is a particular worry because surgeons are just as important in major regional centres as general practitioners are in more remote centres. One of the difficulties has been that surgical training has been largely confined to large city hospitals and there has been no separate rural training program for surgeons.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased to say that, somewhat due to the work of the member for Murray, I have had a number of meetings now with the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. The college is proposing a new, separate rural training program for surgeons. This is very exciting because it offers the prospect that, for the first time, a young doctor on graduation could go to a country area and do all their training in the country rather than having to go to big city hospitals if they want to specialise. It would mean that, in Victoria, someone could go to Geelong, Shepparton, Moe or Warrnambool, they could sit the first part surgical exam there and then be eligible to be chosen for the surgical training program.

The college of surgeons is proposing a new training program that specifically trains people in the needs of rural surgery. Rural surgery is different from city surgery in two respects: one is that rural surgeons need to be trained in obstetrics and the second is that rural surgeons get much more accident and emergency work than a normal general surgeon would. The proposal is to increase surgical training from four years to five years and to have two terms rotating through accident and emergency and through obstetrics.

This is very exciting. It offers the prospect of surgical training over and above existing numbers. It offers the prospect of a specific rural surgical training scheme with the mentoring, with the resources and with the special skills that rural surgeons can provide. I commend the honourable member for Murray for her work in working this up and for the support she has given. I commend the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. The government is going to do absolutely everything it can to see that this comes to fruition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Prime Minister. Is it the case that, as reported in the Australian Financial Review today, Australia's major initiative for APEC—a proposal for free trade in primary energy products by 2000, which was also the centrepiece of the Prime Minister's first major speech on APEC in August—is dead in the water? Given that Australia's other major APEC proposal for a regional business travel card is also reported to be limping, is it not the case that next week's APEC meeting is looming as another major foreign policy embarrassment for the coalition government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government places enormous importance on next week's APEC meeting. The Prime Minister will be attending that conference in order to press the momentum for trade liberalisation within APEC and globally—the matter he discussed with President Clinton yesterday. The Prime Minister proposed at a meeting in Sydney on 1 August that APEC examine the idea of free trade in primary energy before APEC's 2010 and 2020 target dates, and perhaps by the year 2000. This was because the reliable and efficient provision of energy was fundamental to economic growth in the region. It was estimated that removing tariff measures by 2000 in primary energy would increase APEC's real GDP by around $4.5 billion annually. As a major energy exporter, Australia would stand to share in these benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: The government believes that that proposal will take close consideration, and that consideration may take some time. The Minister for Trade and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy are actively pursuing the proposal. As one might imagine, pursuing the proposal will be a matter of extensive discussions and consultations which will continue leading up to this week's meeting. In relation to the business visa, discussions on that are still continuing through the APEC forum. The government has had some positive responses to this initiative. The government expects to have more in the coming days.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services.
—It is better than public meetings, isn't it?
—Yes, it is. Why has the government abolished the register of lobbyists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of the register of lobbyists goes back quite some time. It was established by the Hawke government following the Combe-Ivanov affair. It applied only to a narrow class of lobbyists defined as `a person or company who, for financial or other advantage, represented a client in dealings with government ministers or officials', but, frankly, it was a toothless tiger and its provisions were really unenforceable.

ANSWER.PARA: There is some evidence that the requirements of the scheme were just not being adhered to. In 1993, 1994 and 1995, only eight inquiries were made with the register of lobbyists. There has also been quite a bit of criticism that the register was not available for public scrutiny and that the scheme was an unnecessary hindrance to the business sector. I believe that the need for the register has been overtaken by general changes to the government processes, particularly in light of the active roles taken by the ministers of this government to ensure that their relevant community and business interests are consulted in the decision making process. There will be a revision to the guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. It is to be amended next year. There will be additional guidelines for ministers to observe when dealing with lobbyists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs wants to add to an answer in response to a question from the member for Oxley.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, the member for Oxley asked me a question in my role as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security in this House about the provision of special benefits for newly arrived migrants. I am now able to provide some additional information that might help on that subject.

QUESTION.PARA: Newly arrived migrants who have been in Australia for fewer than 26 weeks and are therefore unable to receive unemployment payments may be eligible for a special benefit if they meet the strict hardship and income tests for that payment. Since 1 April 1996, the hardship test has included the requirement that new migrants must have suffered a significant change in circumstances for reasons beyond their control since arriving in Australia. As at September 1996, 227 migrants were receiving special benefit, because the existing 26-week newly arrived residents waiting period precluded them from jobsearch, newstart, youth training or sickness allowances.

It is not possible to provide a figure on the value of the special benefit paid to new migrants. Special benefit is paid at a discretionary rate which cannot exceed the maximum rate of newstart allowance, which is currently paid at $320.20 per fortnight for a single person over 21 years. Special benefit is reduced by $1 for each dollar of income earned. The rate is also reduced for any in kind support; for example, if the person receives free board and/or lodging.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE OF IRELAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the House. On Sunday of last week Senator Liam Naughten, the President of the Irish Senate, tragically died in a car accident in Ireland. Senator Naughten was aged 52 and was elected firstly to the House of Representatives in Ireland in 1981. He subsequently lost his seat in the lower house and was re‐elected to the Senate where he progressed through to be the equivalent of the President of the Senate a short time later.

PARA.BREAK: The cultural and friendship ties which the Australian people have with the Irish com munity warrant this matter being raised in the House of Representatives today to pay respect in the tragic circumstances of the senator's death, to recognise that at this time his family—his wife and his daughters—are certainly going through that period of grief and, as I have indicated, to recognise very fully the close association there is between this parliament and the Australian people and the Irish Dail and the Irish people.

SPEECH.PARA: He was known throughout this period in parliament as being a very fair man. He came from the west coast of Ireland. He had a great interest as a farmer in all matters relating to the land. My own family, who still have very small—I assure all honourable members on the other side—holdings on the west coast of Ireland, benefited from the representation that the deceased senator made on behalf of the farmers of Ireland. I raise this matter today in respect for the Irish parliament and the family of the deceased senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the remarks of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) and I echo his words. I first met Senator Naughten on a visit to the old country some years ago. I found him to be a very sensitive man. In spite of the fact that he probably never really made the big time in Irish politics, he nevertheless was a great spokesman for his representatives, the small farming community, and was a spokesman on health matters. He was also prominent when he led a delegation of the Irish parliament to Australia recently. His death, as the minister indicates, was a great sadness to us all. I want to be associated with the words of the Minister for Finance.
—I thank the member for Fowler. Whilst this is not a formal condolence motion, I understand that the honourable member for Ballarat would like to make a few remarks as well.

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Bruce (Mr Griffin), the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and I were on a parliamentary delegation some three or four weeks ago and met Senator Naughten. He was an extraordinarily generous man who spoke very highly of the enormous number of friends he had made both in this House and in the other place. I am sure I speak for my colleagues when I echo the sentiments of both gentlemen who have spoken before me.
—I thank all members for their generous comments. Be assured that the President of the Senate and I will be writing separately to the bereaved members of the family.

—Mr Speaker, I have a question to you and it relates to an incident in this place on Tuesday night in which the member for Cowper was seen to move from one side of the chamber to the other after you had appointed tellers for a division, an action which clearly breaches standing order 202 and which is confirmed by a viewing of the tape. Mr Speaker, will you review the tape of the incident and confirm to the House that a breach of standing order 202 did occur? Given that the member for Cowper is the Deputy Speaker and, therefore, is well aware of the provisions of standing order 202, will you instruct the member for Cowper to apologise to the House?

—I thank the member for Hotham for his question to me. I have been distracted somewhat over the last 24 hours by other events and have not yet had occasion to view the tape. It was brought to my attention on the evening, as many of you will recall. I did address a question to the member for Cowper. I will look at the tape and take the matter further as I see fit.

—I have another question to you, Mr Speaker. A viewing of the tape of Tuesday night will also illustrate that I was deliberate obstructed by the Treasurer in attempting to move to the dispatch box. Indeed, I even have a bruise to prove it. Will you report to the House‐
—Show us!
—No, it's only Alex who shows his leg.
—The honourable member for Hotham is addressing a question to me, as I understand it. The Leader of the Opposition is not helping matters.

—I cannot show the bruise. It is only the Minister for Foreign Affairs who is prepared to expose his leg. Mr Speaker, will you report to the House whether such behaviour is appropriate for this place and ascertain whether it was in breach of standing orders? Will you also report on what action you will take to ensure that such a breach by the Treasurer does not occur again?

—I am surprised that the matter was not brought to my attention on the night. However, I will look at the matter separately and report to the House as I see fit. I hope this does not reflect the fact that you did not meet President Clinton yesterday. I thought you may feel aggrieved for some other reason.
—Only that I was prevented from moving a suspension of standing orders that would have enabled us to move by agreement with the other side what they had said we could—and then sought to prevent it.
—As I said, I will reflect further on the matter after viewing the tape, unless the Treasurer wants to involve himself in the discussion.

—I do not, particularly. It is taken as a matter of great jest from a North Melbourne supporter on the other side of the House, but if the tribunal is going to introduce trial by video I want to make it entirely clear that any offence to the member for Hotham and any bruising to his legs which may have caused him pain and suffering amongst any of his friends are deeply regretted by me.

—You should note that the bruising was behind the game. Mr Speaker, could you please inform the House about the cause of the dispute involving house cleaners, members of the LHMU? Is it true that they are to go on strike for 48 hours next week? Is the Joint House Department taking any action to avoid this strike? The Treasurer might laugh about the needs of battlers, the cleaning staff, for whom the strike will mean a significant loss in pay. They would rather not go on strike and cause any inconvenience to the members of this House, their staff and all the people who work in this place as well as the thousands of visitors to this place. I know the potential inconvenience does not worry the Treasurer but it does worry most members. Will you take steps to quickly find a fair and decent resolution to this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have only recently become aware of this problem, but I do have a couple of points to make. I understand that there was a stop‐work meeting from 0700 hours to 0800 hours this morning involving the staff of Limro, the Parliament House cleaning contractor. I further understand that the meeting was called to discuss supervisory and staffing issues, some of which are already before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, with the next hearing scheduled for 28 November.

ANSWER.PARA: Limro are discussing the issues with the union and, with the assistance of the employer organisation, the Confederation of ACT Industry, they will be seeking an earlier conference to resolve the issues. The Joint House Department, which are responsible for the cleaning services in Parliament House, are monitoring the situation to ensure the minimisation of the impact of any industrial action which may eventuate. I will continue my investigations and inform the House further as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you would have noticed that the Australian flag, an important symbol of our nation, is present in this chamber almost grudgingly as an afterthought, unlike the central position given to national flags in some other parliaments. You would also be aware of the fact that the government has moved to ensure that the Australian flag is protected and can never be changed without a plebiscite of the Australian people. Mr Speaker, would you be prepared to consult with the Leader of the House to discuss how the flag could be displayed prominently in a position of honour in this chamber?

—I thank the honourable member for Fisher. I know this is a problem that is very much in the view and purview of the honourable member for Wannon. We do have some ongoing discussions about national flag placement within the chamber. I will happily take up the issue with the Leader of the House, in the hope that we can evolve further and satisfactory resolution to your query.

—The Parliamentary Library has advised me that delivery of items from the Parliamentary Library to members' offices cannot be guaranteed within 24 hours and that indeed it is better if a staff member is dispatched to the Parliamentary Library to collect such items.
—It is because of your cuts!
—In view of the $10.3 billion Beazley black hole you left us, you should not be talking.
—The member for Fisher is addressing a question to me.

—Given the waste of time that sending staff members to the Parliamentary Library all the time would entail, do you find such an extraordinary delay acceptable? What is a reasonable period for delivery after an item is placed into the system, and will you investigate whether delivery can take place within half a working day after the item has been put into the system?
—I do not find a delay of 24 hours extraordinary but, as I am unaware of the issue, I will take it up separately with the library and report back to the House or to you privately.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in addition to the matter raised by the member for Hotham, in which he expressed his concern that the Treasurer had somehow inflicted pain upon him, I raise with you another incident. Earlier in the week, during a double division, I was attempting to move from one side of the chamber to the other when the member for Paterson actually physically restricted my progress.

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I hope the member for Paterson is prepared to restrain himself at the moment.

—I do note, Mr Speaker, that the member for Paterson is acknowledging the incident. While I do not bear any bruises, you will understand that, with a frame weighing about 82 kilograms, I was somewhat concerned about my safety; and, while at no point, I am sure, did the member for Paterson intend any real physical harm to me, you will appreciate that, if he had become a little overenthusiastic and if he had fallen upon me or squeezed me against the table before you, I could have been seriously injured. I ask you also to investigate that matter.

—This has been a most extraordinary week, as many of you would agree. Today's question time is turning out to be a most extraordinary question time. I will take the question on notice, unless the honourable member for Paterson hopes to resolve it for me forthwith.
—If the member for Hunter's personality and his ability are so frail, then perhaps he should be more scared in his electorate, which adjoins mine, than he is in the House.

—Since we are into Tuesday night and the wholly disruptive procedures surrounding Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), I would like to draw your attention to one possible reason why the member for Hotham had difficulty getting to the dispatch box. You will recall that back on 8 October I asked you a question relating to the member for Watson and whether or not the member for Watson was entitled to speak—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: this is nothing like a question to you. That question should be taken out and shot.
—Order! As this is probably the closing question of a fairly torrid after noon, I will allow the member for La Trobe to conclude quickly.

—I intend to. In fact, on 8 October I asked you a question about when the member for Watson was entitled to speak from the dispatch box. I note that on Tuesday night, on three occasions, the member for Watson rushed to try to defeat the member for Hotham getting to the dispatch box. It seemed the whole episode was inappropriate.

—I have a very clear recollection of the occasion. I know very well that the honourable member for Hotham moved a procedural motion which was ultimately, with considerable enthusiasm, seconded rather unsuccessfully by the honourable member for Watson and, after a series of divisions, that resolved the issue. I do not intend to revisit it further.

—Is there an answer to the question posed by the member for Barker on Tuesday making allegations against me concerning the record of Hansard ? My understanding is that the material has been provided to you and I would certainly appreciate at the end of this sitting week your report back to the House. Otherwise I will take a personal explanation.

—As I said, my focus over the last 24 hours has been elsewhere. I know that the information is flowing, or has finally flowed, into my office. If I have an opportunity, I will revisit it this afternoon.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Leave is not granted.
—Is this relevant to the same comment?
—Yes, I've been misrepresented.
—No leave will be granted because you have just asked me a question which I will revisit. I will further advise the House this afternoon if the information I have is complete.
—You knew the truth.
—The honourable member for Werriwa will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —As a question to the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), by way of a contribution to the discussion on the motion, is it his intention in excluding all of private members business from Monday and Tuesday to exclude the consideration of grievances?When I was Leader of the House, it was from time to time necessary to remove private members business to consider government matters. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The pain inflicted on the health of millions of Australians resulting from private health fund premiums rising by up to 15 per cent, massive cuts to public hospital funding as a result of the Howard government's first budget and further disruptions caused by the government's retrospective actions on Medicare provider numbers.
