PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is not in the chamber at the moment. He must be the only person in Australia, certainly the only health minister—
—He is probably out checking the press releases.

—He is probably out checking the press releases, as the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) interjects. He must be the only person in Australia, and certainly the only health minister in Australia, who thinks it is good news when Australia's two largest private health funds increase their premiums by up to 15 per cent. He must be the only one who thinks it is good news—and certainly the only health minister—
—Certainly not families.

—And certainly the pensioners and the families that are going to be hit, as the member interjects, are the ones who will be paying the price because of the decision this government has taken. I am not sure whether the minister is coming in for this debate but, if he is squibbing it, it will be the second occasion in a row that the minister has squibbed an MPI. I hope he is coming into the chamber for the debate because we always like to hear his contributions, and we would like him to respond to some of the points that we are going to raise today about the way this government has turned health policy into a complete shambles.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to remember that this is the minister who claimed that he was absolutely on top of everything, that he was on top of every detail and every scrap of information in his portfolio responsibilities. But this is the minister who said that he was not aware of the MBF press release. In fact, we saw it being handed to him during question time. He claims to be on top of everything but he has to have someone hand him a copy of the MBF press release. Then he cannot even quote from it accurately without misleading the parliament. Then he admits that he has approved increases of up to 15 per cent for this health fund, but he does not know who will be affected. It must be very difficult to be absolutely on top of everything, but to not know about the press release announcing it, to not know whether he has misled the parliament or to not know what the arrangements are for that particular health fund, the fact is that health policy under this government and health policy under this minister is a shambles.

We have the two largest private health funds increasing their premiums by up to 15 per cent, we have federal funding for public hospitals being cut back yet again, and today is the third national day of action by young doctors who are on strike or who are protesting about this government's unfair and retrospective legislation on Medicare provider numbers. So that is the reason we raise this matter of public importance today. That is the reason we are trying to give the minister a chance to come and defend himself in the chamber.

We can only hope that the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) is going to take up the challenge for the honourable member and perhaps speak in defence of his close colleague Dr Wooldridge, the person whom we all know he would like to replace.

Let me start with the issue of health insurance. For the 13 years when they were in opposition, they always had only two policies for health: the first policy was to abolish Medicare and the second policy was to give rebates for health insurance. They were the only two ideas you had in opposition: abolish Medicare and give tax rebates for private health insurance. After a couple of election losses, they had to ditch the first promise of the claim that they were going to abolish Medicare. In the background of course, as we all know, decision after decision in this budget undermines Medicare. Publicly, they are saying that they have ditched that first philosophy. They have ditched the claim that they are going to abolish Medicare.

The second thing, the only thing, they were left with at the 1996 election was this great idea of giving tax breaks for private health insurance. That was going to be the miracle solution to every problem that we have in the health service today. It was going to increase the number of people who would take out private health insurance. It was going to reduce the pressure on our public hospital system.

What we find is that, not even six months before the tax rebate starts to get paid, most of that rebate has been swallowed up in higher premiums. They have spent $1.7 billion and they have got nothing for it. There is nothing to show for it. There certainly is not an increase in the number of people who have taken out private health insurance and there is no evidence at all that there is any pressure being taken off our public hospitals.

The first mistake that this government and this minister made was that, when they decided to provide this tax break of $1.7 billion to the industry, they did not seek any assurances from the private health funds that they would moderate their premium increases. You would have thought that if the government really believed that this tax rebate would solve all the problems in health insurance from 1 July next year, they would have brought in all the health funds, sat them down at the table and asked them for some form of assurance that they would not be jacking up their premiums to steal back that health rebate.

What in fact happened? They announced in the budget that they are locked into giving out this $1.7 billion tax break, yet they had no assurances at all from the industry. Imagine if the government believed that it was good for the nation to buy more steel and offered anyone who bought steel a tax rebate. Imagine if they offered us $1.7 billion worth of tax rebates if we bought more steel stakes and more sheet steel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd support that.

—I know that the member representing Illawarra is a strong supporter of such a policy. The point is: before you give BHP and all the people involved in the steel industry a $1.7 billion tax break, wouldn't you pick up the phone and ring BHP and ask John Prescott if he would agree to moderate his prices for steel so that he would not try to snatch back the $1.7 billion?

SPEECH.PARA: That is what has happened. The government could not be bothered to sit down with the health funds to get some assurances from them about what would happen with increases. What we have seen as a result is that funds are snatching back the benefits that have flowed from this tax rebate.

What we find is that every time these increases take place the government goes into panic mode. Back in August, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who has to be seen to be doing something, decided that in future he would personally consider, vet and ultimately approve every application for increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —He'll fix it up.

—I know that the member for Hunter was hopeful that that might make a difference. But what have we seen? Back in August the Prime Minister blamed a junior official in the Department of Health and Family Services for approving six per cent increases.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening now? The Prime Minister is approving 12 per cent or 15 per cent increases. So it is okay for the Prime Minister to attack a junior official in the department of health for approving six per cent increases, but when the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the minister for health approve increases of double the size there is no blame associated with him. He was forced to do it. But it was okay for the Prime Minister to attack a junior official in the department.

Let me remind the House that, back in August when the Prime Minister intervened, he announced an inquiry which is currently being undertaken by the Productivity Commission. It will report in February. The Prime Minister was asked what would happen to further applications that might be lodged by funds before next February. The Prime Minister's response was, `Well, we'll be disappointed if any funds apply.' He said, `The government would look askance at any applications.' So there is the signal. According to the Prime Minister, not only would they be tough on any future application, but they would also discourage anyone from lodging any more applications between now and February. That is what he said in August.

What has actually happened? The government's own health fund, Medibank Private, has been approved quite a substantial increase. They say that that is an average of almost 13 per cent, with increases of up to 15 per cent. When the government's own health fund ignores the Prime Minister's plea, that is pretty bad. But when the Prime Minister ignores his own plea for restraint then that is even worse. When the Prime Minister, John Howard, ignores John Howard's request for moderation on health insurance increases, something is very wrong.

The minister for health summed it up accurately a month or so ago when he appeared on Meet the Press. In a moment of honesty, he admitted that this was as much about perceptions as it was about reality. That was the admission that the Prime Minister's intervention back in August was nothing but a publicity stunt. The Prime Minister's intervention in August has actually seen, since he has been personally responsible for health insurance fund increases, a doubling of the size of the applications, a doubling of the size of the increases. It was nothing but an attempt to manipulate perceptions.

Question time today was very interesting. We had the minister appear on the AM program this morning for a few minutes and make three mistakes. He got caught out here today at question time. The first mistake he made was that he claimed that the government had in some way beaten down MBF.
What did MBF say in their press release, which was released, by coincidence, yesterday—virtually while the President of the United States was addressing this chamber? The MBF announced:

A notification of contribution rate changes as originally submitted by the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia (MBF), which represents the health funding needs of more than 1.3 million Australians, has been approved by the Federal Government.
This was as originally submitted by MBF and approved by the government. There is obviously someone not telling the truth here. Is it MBF or is it the Minister for Health and Family Services?

We also remind the minister that he said on AM this morning that the average increase for MBF is 6.5 per cent. When we ask him whether he stands by that, whether he is prepared to mislead this House the way he misled the listeners of AM this morning—not deliberately, I am sure—he repeats part of a quote. He quoted quite selectively the rise in contribution rates of 6.5 per cent across the fund's membership overall, but what he did not tell honourable members is that the rest of the sentence said that we get that figure of 6.5 per cent by shoving 300,000 contributors into excess policies. It is like saying that, yes, the price of a Commodore has gone up 15 per cent but you can get a Barina at a cheaper price. If you take up a product which is of lesser value or with a larger excess, of course you would expect the price to be cheaper. That is the way this minister has misled this House and the listeners of the AM program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to take a point of order. The honourable member for Dobell would know that, if he wants to accuse a minister of misleading the House, he must do so by substantive motion.
—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I have not ruled on this one yet.
—On the point of order—
—I will hear the member for Lyons.
—I think the honourable minister ought to be here. He should be in the House to take objection.

— There is no point of order. On the point of order of the honourable member for Stirling: I have been listening very carefully to the member for Dobell, and he did go close to the wind on a couple of occasions. He became aware of that, has moderated his language and will continue to do so.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member's point of order raises the question: where is the minister? He has missed an MPI debate for the second occasion in a row. Where is the minister? This is what the chamber is all about. We know the minister had a bad question time. We know he has been caught out misleading the parliament.
—He's exercising his right to silence.
—So should the member for Banks.

—He might be back in the cone of silence, but the point I want to make is that this $1.7 billion tax break is being swallowed up by increases in premiums that this government is approving. To pay for that $1.7 bill ion tax break for private health insurance, what has happened? The government have cut federal funding for public hospitals by $800 million, they have abolished the Commonwealth dental health program—that is $400 million worth—and they have increased the cost of essential pharmaceuticals by $500 million.

SPEECH.PARA: So that is what has paid for this tax break for the industry: less money for public hospitals, less money for essential dental services and an increase in the cost of pharmaceuticals. That is what the government has had to do—not because of some deficit but because it had not funded its election promises. With the government having spent that $1.7 billion for no benefit whatsoever, we now have to ask ourselves: to improve the quality of health care of Australians, wouldn't it have been better to have spent that $1.7 billion in improving public hospitals by giving them extra money?

I can assure the House that, whatever decisions this government might wish to take in relation to this area, the minister has been exposed this afternoon for misleading this House. He must be the only person in Australia who thinks it is good news when Australia's two largest health funds increase their rates by up to 15 per cent, he must be the only person in Australia who thinks that in some way we can provide better health care to Australians by cutting federal funding for public hospitals and he must be the only Liberal minister for health who has so quickly managed to have gotten so many doctors and so many organisations offside.

So it is no wonder that the minister is not prepared to appear in the House to defend his reputation. We can assure him that the questions will continue and that we will ensure that he continues to be accountable for this shambles of a health policy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been interesting to listen to the shadow spokesman for health, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). He has been handed what could be considered a dream portfolio in opposition. Health is a dream portfolio. And do honourable members know what? He is going to blow it. He is blowing it because he does not understand it. It is an enormously complex area. The demands in health are great and competitive. SPEECH.PARA: The member for Dobell has mentioned three areas in this MPI. He has dealt with private health insurance and has looked at the funding of public hospitals and the restriction of provider numbers for medical students and current interns. I will deal with each of those in due course.

It is very interesting to see the ALP now coming in here concerned about the fact that all these people who hold private health insurance will have their incentives supposedly gobbled up by the premium increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the battlers?

—What about the battlers? This is directed at low and middle income earners. SPEECH.PARA: The member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) has not stayed to hear my contribution, but her former boss, Brian Howe, when he was health minister during 1991-92—he is a fellow traveller of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese)—oversaw a 17 per cent increase on average in private health funds. That was at about the same time that he managed to walk into a broom closet at the end of a press conference during the dying days of the Hawke government.

It has been estimated that a two per cent drop in private health cover costs this nation the equivalent of 325,000 bed days. That is also the equivalent of two teaching hospitals. As I said before, the Hawke and Keating governments oversaw a decline in private health insurance of the order of 30 per cent. That is the equivalent of 30 teaching hospitals around Australia.

It is interesting that the member for Dobell, the ALP's spokesman on health, has not even bothered to stay and listen to this debate. He is not even concerned about the real issues which face Australians in the health area. We are interested in addressing the issue of cost shifting, which is a rort and which he defends. We are interested in preventive health measures. We are interested in giving people some relief for holding private health cover and trying to increase those rates of private health cover so that there is not such an incredible demand on the public system.

Labor contributed to that decline in private health insurance by such initiatives as changing the Medicare rebate from 85 to 75 per cent. They removed the reinsurance pool and they totally neglected to address the issue of cost shifting. In fact, back in August, the shadow minister did not even understand what cost shifting was. He had no idea that it was so complex. The ALP also removed the Commonwealth bed day subsidy. All of those actions by the previous government contributed to a 39 per cent increase in premiums.

About five million Australians will be eligible for private health insurance tax incentives. It is important to emphasise, especially to those 700,000 Australians whose incomes are below $20,000 but who have been holding private insurance, that this incentive will be available as a tax rebate, but it will also be available as an equivalent amount by way of a reduced premium cost for those who do not pay enough tax. So for pensioners and others who are earning less than $20,000 a year and who hold private health insurance, it does not matter if they do not pay tax, they will be eligible; they will just pay a reduced premium.

BREAK.PARA: It should be remembered that Labor had a few health ministers during its period in office. Carmen Lawrence's health legislation did nothing to address the haemorrhaging that was going on in private health insurance. Looking at the issue of cost shifting, if the shadow minister is concerned about cost shifting, which we have addressed, he is in a sense defending a rort. There are plenty of visible signs of this rort. In a Melbourne public hospital, there is a bulk‐billing Medicare clinic which specialises in things like plaster cast removal. That is a direct shifting of cost from what should be a state responsibility to the Commonwealth government. In another Melbourne hospital, there are 62 privatised outpatient clinics. This is all quite contrary to the Medicare agreement.

Health ministers agreed at their June 1995 meeting in Alice Springs to recover annually the growth that was occurring in cost shifting in that period. That is all we have done. The member for Dobell refers to decreases in funding to public hospitals. It relates to addressing this whole issue of cost shifting. I would like to refer to a few quotes. Here is one:
. . . as the Labor Party had always been a bit biased against private health insurance. . .

That was said by a former health minister in the Keating government, Graham Richardson. It is interesting to note that Paul Keating, in the 1993 election campaign, said that people did not need private health insurance, that Medicare would be enough. Richardson went on to say:
I was never comfortable with the thought of wealthy people elbowing battlers out of queues in public hospitals.

That was the situation that occurred under the Labor government. The member for Grayndler talks about battlers. While he was never a fellow traveller of Graham Richardson, Graham Richardson went on to say:
Even the thought that the Liberals are prepared to make the rich pay more when the Labor Party would not is enough to scare the hell out of me.
If they are so concerned about private health insurance and people not being in the system, why is it that they never addressed this issue? Richardson went on to say:
. . . there were those in the party who thought any suggestion that public hospitals were not being adequately funded amounted either to cowardice in being unable to face up to funding cuts—
that would be members of the Right like the member for Dobell—
or treason for daring to suggest anything could be wrong with Medicare.

That would be members of the Left like the member for Grayndler. Finally, I would like to speak on the issue of the restriction of Medicare provider numbers. There is no doubt this was a tough decision. It was tough on interns and it was tough on current medical students. It was based on the premise that each doctor who goes onto the Medicare benefits schedule adds something like $175,000 to $225,000 through consultations, pharmaceuticals, radiology and pathology services. The OECD has estimated that at least 55 per cent of health care costs are supply driven.

This was a difficult decision. We have looked at a number of areas. We are actually addressing the area of reducing medical school intakes. We are making it more difficult for overseas trained doctors to practise in Australia by imposing a 10‐year moratorium on those doctors practising. That will apply after 1 January 1997. In a previous speech on the bill which related to this issue, the ALP spokesman for health said this:
The Labor Party certainly understands the importance of seeking to manage the medical work force. . .

He is so right there, because it is very interesting to look at what has been said on this issue by health ministers in the previous government. First of all, before this proposal had even been floated, this year in Australian Doctor , Brian Howe said:
Restricting provider numbers should be considered to limit the general practice workforce.
He went on to say:
. . . perhaps provider numbers could control the numbers of GPs.
What did the health minister after him, Graham Richardson, say about it? In the Bulletin of October 1996 he said:
I hope Michael Wooldridge, the Federal Minister for Health, stands his ground and limits Medicare provider numbers for new medical graduates from November.
He went on to say:
The AMA was told in 1993 that restrictions on Medicare provider numbers were inevitable. I told the AMA that this would happen, regardless of who governed Australia.

Last of all, the senior general practice adviser of the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), the last health minister in the Keating government, confirmed that they had sought legal advice which indicated that it was possible to restrict access to provider numbers.

It is all very well for the ALP to come in here and say that this is a terrible thing the government is doing. We know it is a tough thing. All members on this side of this House know that it is a tough thing. The problem has been that, in order to keep Medicare going, we had to address some of the uncontrolled increases in cost that have occurred in Medicare.

In fact, I believe that most medical graduates will be able to get work after this measure is introduced. There will be 400 places for general practitioners and, as of next year, there will be 760 specialty posts available. The increase in specialty posts has been due to an expansion in positions in ENT, orthopaedics, anaesthetics and urology. There will also be positions for 20 doctors to go into medical administration and 20 doctors to go into medical research. Next year, rather than 400 general practice training positions, it will be 420. This year, overseas trained doctors had 89 places. When you put that altogether, the number of Australian graduates being approximately 1,200 and 89 overseas trained doctors getting places, it means that almost every Australian graduate—and not all of them will want to go on to practise medicine—will be able to get a training position which will allow them to be better trained before they go onto the Medicare scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support this MPI put forward by the shadow health minister, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), today. SPEECH.PARA: I intend to begin by addressing the massive cuts to public hospital funding announced this week, cuts which back up the cuts that were announced in the budget. SPEECH.PARA: These latest cuts to health are just more in a series that the coalition has introduced since the election, further proof that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Family Services do not consider providing Australians with a decent, fair and accessible health system is important. There are cutbacks in federal funding for public hospitals of $800 million, cutbacks to the dental health program of $400 million and cutbacks to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $500 million. The problem for this government is that they cannot get over their obsessive hatred of the public sector. At the same time, the coalition seem to be pretty generous to their mates in the private sector. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House grants leave for Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks to produce the following records in evidence in proceedings before the High Court in the cases
(a) Laurence Nathan Levy v. The State of Victoria and Others
(b) Lange v. Australian Broadcasting Corporation

PARA.TAB: Parliamentary Debates, House of Representatives, 15 November 1994—Speeches of Mr Lavarch—(pp 3336‐3342).

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is intended to grant a request conveyed to the House in the letter tabled by the Speaker on Tuesday. The letter is from Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks, solicitors, and seeks permission of the House to adduce in evidence certain extracts from the Hansard . The request concerns a speech on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994. Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks act for the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, which is, we gather, seeking leave to intervene in two matters scheduled to be heard before the High Court. These are the proceedings listed in the notice of motion.

The motion itself does not address the substantive issue of privilege itself. That is a matter governed by the law as expounded in section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. The well-known immunity of parliamentary proceedings from being impeached or questioned in court is inherited from article 9 of the Bill of Rights; however, subsection 16(5) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act does in fact state that neither the 1987 act nor the Bill of Rights is taken to prevent the admission of parliamentary records in connection with a matter arising under section 57 of the constitution or the interpretation of an act.

While there is some judicial authority for the view that the permission of the House is not required on the procedural question of actual production of the parliamentary records, as distinct from the substantive question of the use to which they can be put, the House has never formally abandoned the position that permission should be sought—hence, today's motion.

There are a number of precedents for permission being granted. In fact, three instances have arisen in the present sittings—more recently on 29 October—in relation to the same proceedings as referred to in the present request, but of course different extracts from the Hansard.

Further background on these matters is contained in House of Representatives Practice at pages 690 to 698. I am confident that, if it grants the request for leave, the House will be acting in full accord with the precedents which exist.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I had commenced my remarks about the Import Processing Charges Bill 1996 before question time intervened. I was dealing with the responsibilities of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) for Customs. I was making the observation that, apart from this bill, putting up charges for the use of customs as well as increasing red tape for small business was against the background of some very significant cuts to the Customs Service, thereby restricting its ability to perform its duties. Those cuts total $70 million over the next four years, the loss of 105 jobs in Victoria, 65 in New South Wales, 60 in the ACT, 25 in Queensland and 24 in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government that, on the one hand, is saying it will increase employment but, on the other, is taking deliberate steps that indeed cut it back. The government has also introduced a complete ending of all airport shift work. This is a very interesting decision by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs in relation to his own department, because it comes from a minister who, before he was the minister and when in opposition, told his colleagues:
Any budgetary cuts to [customs inspection and clearance procedures] would slow down the clearance of goods, holding up businesses, and result in a lesser frequency of inspections.
Budget cuts would also result in a decline in the number of audits undertaken and hence revenue raised . . .
Any decline in the intelligence activities will impact on Customs' law enforcement activities and, in particular, their success.

You have not only the impact in terms of businesses wanting to get access to their goods and that being held up but also the minister admitting before he implemented these decisions that they would hamper the ability of the Customs Service to carry out its own activities.

The minister has also presided over a $400 million cut to the diesel fuel rebate. Presumably, this cut came about because they claimed there were $400 million of rorters in the scheme. What the government claimed in advance of the diesel fuel rebate decision, in saying that they had kept their election promise, was they would not cut the rebate except in cases of abuse of the system. The minister is really saying to the farmers and the miners of this country, `We kept the diesel fuel rebate but, really, it is $400 million less. The reason it is $400 million less is that you are rorting the scheme.' This is the stock defence by the government to a lot of the cuts that they have imposed. Rather than enter the dialogue and the debate about these things, they simply assert the fact that there has been a rort.

Turning to the minister's responsibility in the small business side of his portfolio, the minister recently released the Charlie Bell review of small business red tape. This was another of the election promises of the government. Interestingly enough, when this report was released, it was not tabled in this parliament. So we have not been able to gain access to copies of this report in the normal way that one would expect.

I am told that the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) had his office ring the minister's office to get a copy of the report. The person ringing on behalf of the member for Shortland was asked which party the member was from. When they said it was for the ALP, they were told, `You've got to go to the government bookshop.' In other words, what we have here is a government that is so into openness, accountability, improved understanding and improved information that it will only release its report to its mates—having accused us of being in the mates' brigade—and, so far as the Labor Party is concerned, we have to pay for the privilege.

BREAK.PARA: This is hardly what you would call an even-handed approach in government, but it is the way in which the minister operates in relation to his portfolio. I think it is in keeping with the way in which he operates his private businesses about which we have already demonstrated there are so many appearances of conflict of interest that they have become legion. Yet his view on all of these things is to deny either responsibility or conflict, or both, and say that so far as he is concerned he will keep it all to himself.

The Charlie Bell review was about finding ways of meeting the Prime Minister's commitment to cut small business red tape by 50 per cent over the term of the government, which was a promise reconfirmed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as recently as last month. The Charlie Bell report has, in effect, set a benchmark for this government.

We know the government itself does not like setting benchmarks. It will not set a target for the unemployed, it will not set a target for employment growth, it will not reaffirm targets in important areas of economic activity; but it is prepared, in election promise terms, to set a target of cutting red tape by 50 per cent. Let us understand the importance of that: targets for people do not matter but targets for paper do.

When we ask, `What does the 50 per cent target reduction mean?' they sort of go mute. They say, `We have got a commitment of 50 per cent over the term of the government.' What is revealing in this report is the ability to measure and benchmark that target. It stated in the report that the average small business spends four hours a week on government red tape—translated, the promise is to cut red tape to two hours. Labor will be keeping a close eye on whether the government does in fact keep to that promise.

I see that the minister is not even here in the House. He was not in the House when this debate was on just before question time and he is still not here. No doubt he is looking after the affairs of his private companies. They are more important than the matters before parliament.

The minister has made a dreadful start in cutting red tape. As these bills show, one of the minister's first acts is to increase tax. Remember the promises made before the election, `No increase in taxes under a Liberal government.' Read my lips, honest John: no increase in taxes. This is what this bill does. Don't you think that a charge imposed on businesses that have to use the services to get their goods constitutes a charge or a tax? That is what he has put up. He runs around the country promising to cut red tape and not put taxes up; yet this is a bill that increases taxes as well as increasing the red tape.

The package comprises three bills which the Deputy Speaker has indicated we are dealing with cognately. They give legislative authority for the measures announced in the budget to introduce full cost recovery for import related services delivered by the Australian Customs Service. It involves the imposition of 13 fees and charges—in other words, taxes. This is a broken promise—obviously not a core promise—and this is a government committed to helping small business. The new taxes will apply from 1 January 1997.

Overall, the bills will not be opposed by Labor because they do expand the user‐pays arrangements for Customs begun when we were in office. They apply only to imports and they are levied either on the importer or the shipper. But the opposition does have some major concerns with the impact the bills will have on small businesses and in some regions. We will therefore be moving a series of amendments in the Senate to protect the people whose livelihoods are threatened by aspects of these bills.

In essence, Labor is concerned that the bills will lead to extra costs for imports of materials used in manufacturing here in Australia at a time when business incentive measures are being stripped away all through the budget. What the charges will do is also have a greater impact on regional ports where Customs have closed their offices and may impact negatively on regional ports such as Geelong. The measures will also increase small business red tape.

The government claims they have consulted widely with industry on the introduction of these charges. This appears mainly to have occurred within the confines of the Customs National Consultative Committee. The intention of Labor is therefore to move amendments as I will outline. The first is a four‐year phase‐in period for the reduction threshold at which the import entry charge is levied from $1,000 to $250. As it stands now in the proposal, the reduction in the threshold may have a substantial impact on small importers who supply niche markets with specialised product from overseas and to low volume importers, typically small business. The immediate imposition of the lower threshold could drive such firms out of business by imposing the extra $22.80 charge for electronic entries or $44.55 for manual entries.

Secondly, we will be moving an amendment for a four‐year phase‐in period for the new fees. This is particularly important for fees on manual entry which are to be levied at a much higher level than the fees on electronic entry. What this does is threaten disproportionately small businesses which do not have access to the electronic facilities or which lack the expertise to utilise the service. While Customs' advice is that they plan to increase access to electronic entering by installing computers at Customs shopfronts, airports, international mail exchanges and customs houses, where many small commercial importers currently lodge their manual claims, these facilities will not be in place on 1 January when the high fees are proposed to be applicable. It therefore seems reasonable that a phase‐in period apply.

Thirdly, in respect of the licensing charge for section 17B premises, we will seek to introduce a two‐tiered fee based on the turnover of the individual premises. This will help protect premises and jobs based in regional Australia where the turnover may be lower but the service is no less important.

So whilst not opposing the overall thrust of this bill we do want to highlight the concerns that we have. The first is with the way the minister has been administering his portfolio—the very fact that he is still not in the chamber is evidence of his neglect and the contempt in which he holds this important piece of work. The second is with the fact that we see inherent in this bill a breach yet again of election commitments on two fronts—first, that it does involve an increase in taxes on small businesses and, second, that it adds to the paperwork that businesses will have to undertake—and the third is in relation to the specific detail of the bill. We think the decision to implement and move completely to full cost recovery on 1 January is not appropriate. For that reason we will be supporting amendments which seek to provide a phase‐in for the measures sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay, Alex, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) for 20 minutes of his half hour spoke about the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser). He devoted only his last 10 minutes to the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. In my remarks I will devote my total time to remarks on the bill. This bill is one of the three bills designed to implement cost recovery for import related services delivered by the Australian Customs Service. The three bills in this legislative package provide for the imposition and collection of 13 charges and fees on import related services. The 13 imposts are located in three pieces of legislation, two new charges bills—the Import Processing Charges Bill and the Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bill—as well as the Customs Amendment Bill. These bills will result in full cost recovery for commercial customs activities directly and indirectly required to process imports. This was among the measures announced by the government in the 1996‐97 budget.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1 January 1997 the Australian Customs Service will apply full cost recovery for all commercial customs activities directly and indirectly required to process imports. The services to be covered by the new charges are cargo reporting, both sea and air, import entry processing—sea, air and post—and licensing of approved places for the examination of goods. This measure forecasts a net budget impact of $45.9 million per annum. This represents $66.5 million less the $18.5 million currently collected for the use of IT facilities. To coincide with this measure, Customs has taken the opportunity to streamline refund procedures and associated cost recovery, and adjust current charges for out of hours work or work by customs officers in locations where they do not usually work.

Charges have been determined from a detailed activity based costing of customs services. The costing methodology has been reviewed by external auditors. The charges are limited to the calculated costs of delivering the functions and will be reviewed annually to ensure that they reflect only the costing structure. Costs to process import transactions by Customs will be examined annually and any material changes will be reflected in an annual review of the charges.

Before outlining the industry impact of these changes, I would like to draw attention to the industry consultation which took place after the budget. After the budget announcement, members of the Customs National Consultative Committee, the CNCC, were briefed at a special meeting about the nature of the proposed charges. This committee comprises representatives from the Australian Air Transport Association, the Australian Chamber of Shipping, the Australian Federation of International Forwarders, the Customs Brokers Council of Australia—CBCA—the International Air Couriers Association, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Law Council of Australia and the Institute of Chartered Accountants.

Their feedback resulted in some changes being made to the charges for entry processing and the methods of collection. This committee met again in September where the charges were once more the subject of discussion. Meetings have been held with various sectors of the importing community, such as the air express couriers and the cargo terminal operators, in regard to establishing the most efficient collection methods for the charges.

In meeting with a variety of industry sectors, Customs was made aware of some difficulties that the collection of cargo reporting fees and screening fees would impose on cargo terminal operators and shipping companies for manual reporting charges and on air express couriers for screening charges. Special arrangements may be entered into for the collection of the charges, including periodic settlement arrangements to coincide with the operating environment and billing cycles experienced by many of the firms in the importing community.

In addition to meetings, Customs has conducted a series of industry briefing sessions in all state and territory capital cities and in several regional centres. These sessions have provided an opportunity for Customs to explain details about the charges and how they will be collected. At the same time, the sessions provided a valuable forum for feedback from all sectors of the importing community, much of which has influenced the implementation decisions.

The impact on the industry is as follows: 103,000 importers generated around 2.2 million customs entries in 1995, containing 7.2 million entry lines; based on 1995 data, 95 per cent of importers have entries averaging less than 10 lines per entry; 65 per cent of importers bring in four or fewer entries—averaging 3.5 lines or less per year—and would incur total costs of approximately $100 per annum; 99 importers generated 1,500 or more entries each, together accounting for around 15 per cent of all entries; four of these importers generated over 10,000 entries, the largest importer bringing in just over 14,000 entries.

Customs' annual funding will be reduced by an amount equivalent to that raised through cost recovery. This measure therefore aligns the cost of processing imports with that sector of the community—that is, the importers—which generates customs work, rather than spreading the costs across all taxpayers.

This measure is consistent with the general thrust of government policy, which increasingly sees a closer alignment of costs with sectors of the community that benefit from the provision of public services. The user‐pays system is already used in relation to the recovery of the costs of processing passengers at international airports, through the passenger movement charge.

Customs currently recovers part of the costs of its electronic systems through charges levied on importers for import entries. This proposal sees an extension of a current cost recovery regime. The extension of the current charging arrangements relates only to commercial import processing. It does not cover activity associated with Customs' community protection function relating to the detection and interception of prohibited imports and drugs.

The government recognises Customs' important role in this area and in this budget has provided funds to Customs to significantly increase the use of sophisticated technology to maintain and enhance its community protection capability. Nor will charges apply to the processing of export transactions. The exemption of exports from the new user‐pays system is a recognition of the key role export industries will play in improving Australia's trade balance.

The Australian Customs Service has played a leading role in the development of electronic systems which have enhanced its capacity to facilitate the efficient movement and quick release of cargo. This ultimately benefits the Australian community. The charging regime established reflects the efficiencies of electronic data reporting and will continue to do so.

For example, the cargo management strategy—an exposure draft which was released in August 1996—identifies opportunities for enhanced information mechanisms for information exchange between Customs and industry. Within the five‐year reach of that strategy, the key elements are: continued recognition of the importance of existing computer systems; to adopt enabling technology which simulates integration of those systems and allows more flexible reporting of information; to permit rationalisation of information needs and reduce duplication and redundancy; and to adopt new technologies which allow more sophisticated manipulation of information for risk management.

The end result will be a seamless and flexible system which will simplify information management for all clients and cater for future requirements. The delivery of these types of efficiencies will have a bearing on the ultimate costs to provide Customs' services to its client base.

In the cost recovery implementation, significant inroads have been achieved in creating flexible systems both for liability assessment and payment. This is consistent with the thrust of the cargo management strategy. For example, settlement arrangements for manual reporting charges have been made more flexible. As a result of consultation with the cargo terminal operators, the legislation now allows for the CEO of Customs to agree to terms for settlement—potentially monthly—for some cargo reporters, rather than payment at the time of reporting. In recognition of the need to maximise electronic processing of information and to not disadvantage those operators that lodge electronic reports with Customs, Customs has undertaken IT enhancements that will result in the retention of electronic data and minimisation of reporting costs.

After an approach by the air express couriers, an arrangement for payment of the screen free charge has been agreed by Customs. This arrangement is represented by the payment of a reporting levy against formal entries lodged by those companies entering into the arrangement. For those companies that do not wish to participate in the alternative settlement scheme, monthly settlement will apply.

The cost recovery implementation has enabled Customs to address a series of longstanding anomalies in its administration. An example is that for several years the air courier industry has criticised an inequity existing between entry requirements for air cargo imports and importation by post.

Specifically, commercial air cargo imports valuing $250 or more have required an entry, whereas requirements for entries in the postal environment are for imports valuing $1,000 or more. The new arrangements see this anomaly disappear with a requirement for the lodgement of an entry for all commercial cargo over $250 in value.

In summing up, I would like to refer briefly to the background behind the budget decision to apply cost recovery for commercial customs activities relating to the processing of imports. As we in this House are aware, the government was faced with a huge task to turn around the Australian economy. The decision to introduce cost recovery to the Customs import process is in line with the government's general acceptance of the user‐pays principle.

BREAK.PARA: The new charge will have a beneficial side effect—it will attribute direct costs of the import clearance process to goods imported, thereby removing the burden for funding this process from the community generally.

While the cost recovery is to do with commercial activity, it is also true that the import clearance process accomplishes far more than just collection of statistics and revenue. The entire customs process supplies importers with a mechanism which provides awareness of, and monitors compliance with, Australian safety standards, labelling and other consumer protection laws.

In addition, there is an obvious cost in preventing imported goods being used inadvertently or deliberately as a method of bringing in illicit drugs and other contraband. Goods manufactured in Australia do not present the same risk.

Finally, the deliberate exemption of the export process from the user‐pays regime, as I mentioned earlier, is also extremely important in the context of Australia's future. It is a recognition of the key role export industries will play in improving Australia's trade balance, creating more jobs and reducing the deficit—a task this government has made its highest priority. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is another ill‐thought out bill that has some serious ramifications for small business throughout Australia. It is something that has been thrown together. Based on the last speaker's comments, everything has to be met to meet some deficit reduction while small business suffers. Whether it is R&D research or any sort of level of assistance to business, the government's attitude appears to be that we can go without businesses in Australia as long as we have the deficit right.

PARA.BREAK: I wish to address the changes to the charges levied for small business to clear customs. Some changes are to streamline processing by adding an electronic link to allow faster clearances. But new charges are being levied on the processing of the cargo reports, import entry processing and the licensing of the approved place for the examination of goods. Customs are trying to cut the costs of process ing to `ensure that costs recovered do not exceed costs calculated to process import transactions'. They reckon the charges are limited to the calculated costs of delivering functions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like either the minister or someone on that side to tell me why a small importer who brings in on each consignment an average of between $300 and $400 worth of goods by post suddenly will be hit with a charge of at least $42.65 customs and sometimes up to $80 just for the privilege of having to take longer to clear his goods because the customs officer has been moved.

This particular small business, situated in a country area in northern Tasmania, imports goods from England, Scotland, Ireland and Canada from suppliers who previously could not make their goods available here due to the distance of the markets. Their import orders are not large because of the market size and the variety of interests of their customers. Currently, when goods arrive they undertake an informal customs clearance which takes no more than about five minutes.

With this clearance, they inform Customs of the value of the goods, the sales tax and duty payable and the cost in Australian dollars. This is then faxed to Customs in Hobart and the goods are dispatched. All these consignments are worth under $1,000 and are imported by post. The amendments moved by the government have put a stop to informal customs clearances. Their user‐pays, cost recovery scheme will now involve a $44.55 charge for manual lodgment. This particular business will have to travel to Launceston to lodge it in person. It is going to cost for the lodgment and it is going to cost the small business money in travel.

The alternative offered is that they can use electronic lodgment at a cost of $29.65. However, the advice on this was that they would need a customs agent to process transactions to qualify for this reduced fee. The agent has been charging this business $60 per consignment before they started doing the informal customs clearance themselves. From past experience, they believed that this fee would rise with the more formal clearances and licensing fees. They could be charged a fee of $80 by a customs agent plus the electronic lodgment charge of $29.65. They quite rightly point out that, on a consignment of $300, these charges will make the business unprofitable. Although some charges might be applicable for large consignments, the very nature of this particular business prevents them from placing larger orders.

They said that they do not consider that a consignment of 15 books, usually worth $300, warrants a charge of $44.55 to process. This is not the sort of charge they can absorb into the cost price of the article. The cost of customs to this particular small business is 15 per cent of the transaction. There is no way any small business can cope with that sort of cost.

The government should have looked at ways of reducing the book work involved before proceeding with this legislation. There has been no attempt to discriminate between $1,000 orders and $300 orders. The scheme in the past worked quickly—the duty was paid where and when it should be. The time taken for the processing by the customs officer was minimal—maybe five minutes—and it could be done by fax, which cut down on travelling time. To change this to the cumbersome fee collection regime which is being suggested here without some minimum cut off for the value of the goods coming in—for example, $1,000—seems to be bureaucracy gone mad. Why change a scheme that works well, collects its money and costs little to implement? Has Mr Hilmer put his nose in here too?

Change to so-called `streamline elements of two existing fees' in this case is change for change sake rather than change to achieve efficiency. The government has obviously decided to cut people out of the Customs Service and is using the user‐pays principle to justify the cuts.

This bill also seeks to charge depots a licence fee of $5,000. I have sought advice on this from customs agents in Tasmania. Some have said that this will result in organisations being unable to afford to operate. Certainly, the smaller ones would have great difficulty. The customs department has informed me that there are 22 depots in Tasmania and they are currently served by 46 customs agents. The government wants to cut the number of agents, so it makes the depots unprofitable and they will close down. Only the big ones will continue to operate. Small business will be the loser. Small business is hit again.

The minister should be sticking up for small business, not imposing more charges on it. He comes in and answers questions in question time by saying that the government is in the process of minimising costs to small business. This bill is going to impose more costs on small business.

The department mentioned that a lot of the costs will be eliminated once electronic systems are in place at the main airports and post offices. I suggest we put some of those bureaucrats into the middle of Tasmania, in outback New South Wales or in Far North Queensland for a few months and see how they get on. It takes me a minimum of three days to get a letter from Canberra into my office.

Most of these isolated areas barely have telephones or decent television reception, let alone lines to allow such things as electronic data transfer. This means people have to drive to their nearest major airport. For people on the west coast of Tasmania that means travelling for 3½ hours, and for most of the other people in my electorate of Lyons it means travelling for two hours. The Public Service is supposed to be a public service to help the private sector drive our economy. All this government seems to want to do is put obstacles in its way.

The governments's intention to sell Telstra, its inability to get Optus and Telstra together to do the cabling—the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications and the Arts, gave some waffle on how this was somebody else's fault; he did not make any contribution to this debate—mean that the country and regional areas have no hope of being connected to anything, certainly not without paying a considerable amount of money in future. So much for the big argument of helping people in country areas.

BREAK.PARA: As I said in the beginning, this bill is badly thought out. It will have all sorts of implications if it is carried in its present form. Some minor but critical amendments should be made to make all the difference to the small business sector. There is a strong argument to leave any major changes to charging on depots until the electronic transfer is available outside the major city areas. This should not take long if the commitment to do it is there. There should still be an ability to clear goods to the value of $1,000 through the informal clearance declaration.

I think the government should address these points before the bill goes too much further and before we end up in a disastrous situation for many small operators throughout Australia. There is no doubt that there are some major problems within this bill. They need to be addressed before the bill is passed by the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the bluster of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) in his second reading speeches, the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2) and cognate bills are blatant revenue raisers, nothing more and nothing less. The rationale employed by the minister is that they are cost recovery measures.

SPEECH.PARA: `Cost recovery' are buzz words. They are buzz words used increasingly by successive governments since the early 1980s to justify new imposts because those governments chose to legislate in certain ways. In other words, the need for so-called cost recovery is created first by government legislation, then or some time later down the track the government decides that its laws have created the need for that very same government to claw back some, all or more of the cost that its own laws were responsible for inflicting.

These bills are a classic example. Hitherto, there was no licence fee for customs depot licensing charges. Previously, import processing charges might have been expected to raise $17.6 million in a full year. But with the passage of this legislation the take will increase by just over $44 million or 250 per cent. A more modest—or is it less ambitious—increase is in the cost of section 85: warehouse fees, computer recovery, refund applications and overtime for official services of $372,000. Nearly 11 per cent extra will be raised.

The full‐year addition to revenue raised under the provision of all three bills being debated cognately will be just under $46 million—an increase of 69 per cent. This is not a bad little earner in times of low inflation. It might be laughable, given in particular the minister's crazy justifications for the imposts—if we could ignore some of the more serious implications.

Where will the costs fall, for example? The costs will be borne by small businesses and consumers—a pretty good double for the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. He might very well be better described by the minister versus small business and anti‐consumers. It might be fair to ask the minister how he can look either proprietors of affected small businesses or consumers in the eye, but of course he does not. If this is an example of a minister who is for something, in this case small business and presumably consumers, God help us all if he were against them.

Most import agents may be held up as classic examples of small business proprietors. Most other importers are small business owners who do not need, so far in our history, the cost of employing import agents. It is unarguable that these new charges will fall disproportionately on small businesses and their clients. But it does not stop there. Many, if not most, of the clients of import agents are in turn small businesses. These are the clients of import agents.

It is not clear if the minister expects agents to absorb the charges. Surely he is not so silly. He must know that all the additional costs these measures impose will be passed on down the chain, where necessary, through small businesses to the consumers of imported goods. So much for Labor's rorting of the wholesale sales tax system. They must have extracted all the blood that can be got out of that particular stone. The charges raised in these bills are no more and no less than an indirect tax by another name.

BREAK.PARA: So the coalition government, with the willing cooperation of the minister, had to scrape the bottom of the barrel and devise new charges, or exorbitantly raise existing ones, all to be embraced under the political speak terminology `cost recovery'. By way of an aside, if this parliament ever agrees to adopt an across‐the‐board expenditure tax of one kind or another, it will only be as a substitute for existing indirect taxes including, hopefully, those now before the House. Levied at 15 per cent, one could not expect more because the cupboard is bare.

The need for the responsible minister to explain further is not confined to his rhetoric which purports to support either small businesses or consumers. How often have we heard him rabbiting on in this place about the need to cut regulation and red tape, particularly as it affects the small business sector? It was a temptation to say that he may even have waxed eloquent on the subject, except some would not forgive me for such an exaggeration. Here we have another abundance of red tape, which the private business sector in general and small businesses in particular have to unravel at their great cost.

Just examine for one minute the charges to be levied for processing imports. For an import entry application lodged electronically, the amount to be paid is $29.65 plus 20c per line after line 10. But, if the application is not lodged electronically, the charge will be $51.40 plus $1 per line after the first line. We do not seem to be told whether the importer has to have IBM compatible equipment to electronically lodge an application for an import entry, but it is probably buried in some obscure regulation either already at large or to be devised.

The next category involving a charge or charges is an application for import entry by air or post lodged electronically, in which case the fee will be $22.80 plus 20c per line after line 10. A similar application not lodged electronically will cost $44.55 plus $1 per line after the first line. For sea cargo, a fee of $2.60 per manifest line will be payable, $3 per house or straight line airway bill, whatever that might mean, and finally a screen fee charge of $2.40 per house or straight line airway bill.

The total to be raised by these charges will be $61,675,000 in a full year. However inconsequential the descriptions of the charges may seem, the cost to be added to imports is no mean figure. I have heard about journalists and others being paid by the line or according to the number of words written, but this one takes the cake. Perhaps the best advice we can give to affected importers is that they lodge manual applications, write in very small letters and use abbreviations of the kind used by the real estate industry in advertisements used to flog off houses. But even then, at $1 per line after the first line as well as an up-front charge, almost in both cases about double that of the electronically lodged equivalent, the manual alternative remains less than attractive. The message to hundreds of affected importers is that, if you do not already have a computer compatible with that used by the Customs Service, go out and buy one. But isn't that a cost of compliance?

An interesting outcome, if not intent, of the electronic lodging provisions in this legislation is that boutique importers who do not have this capacity may be driven to engage an import agent. Do‐it‐yourself business people who have hitherto made their own arrangements with a minimum of fuss might be better served to hire an agent rather than pay the premium to be imposed on the cost of manual lodgments. And all for what—to suit the convenience of a government agency, a convenience that the minister has not even attempted to argue in his presentation. Such an outcome will involve a further increase in compliance costs for affected importers not previously needing to hire import agents.

Talking about the cost of compliance, I have thumbed through all three explanatory memoranda and I cannot for the life of me find an estimate of the cost of compliance. Surely we have to have superseded copies, because I have heard the minister talk, almost to the point of tedium, about the evils of compliance costs inflicted on small businesses by government legislation and regulation. Perhaps the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who is at the table, could give me the correct memoranda, which would undoubtedly include estimates of the cost of compliance with these bills, given the minister's strident advocacy in opposition to and awareness of burdensome costs of compliance with all types of legislation, let alone that for which he has sole responsibility.

It is obvious that such estimates are possible because each memorandum contains estimates of the amounts to be raised in a full year in each of the seven categories to which reference has already been made. For example, category 1, where an application for import entry is lodged electronically—the charge being $29.65 plus 20c a line after line 10—will raise $24,386,000. The manual equivalent, the second category, will raise $585,000 in a full year. Category 3 will raise in a full year $30,314,000, and so it goes on down to category 7.

If it is possible to estimate the revenue, it is equally possible to estimate the cost of compliance. But compliance cost estimates are nowhere to be found, and I do not see anyone rushing around the chamber trying to find me more up‐to‐date memoranda which might include the information. It raises the question: was this proposed legislation referred to the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, which has recently reported to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)?

That question gives rise to two further queries. Firstly, if it was, what recommendations does the report contain about the increased and burdensome compliance costs which will ensue under these bills and be incurred by importers and consumers of imported products? The second supplementary question is: if it was not, why not? The sad truth appears to be that the quantum of compliance costs has not even been considered by the minister or, if it has, a deliberate decision has been taken to leave the estimates out of his second reading speech and the accompanying memoranda. In either case, a lack of both honesty and courage is in evidence.

The minister also seeks to make a virtue of the exemption of exports under what he quaintly describes as `the new user‐pays system' and goes on to acknowledge the contribution of exporters to improving our trade balance, creating more jobs and reducing the federal deficit. So it is demonstrated that the user‐pays principle is not inviolate and, to the extent that it is applied to the Customs Service, will continue to absorb the costs of servicing exports.

I am not arguing against that, but the point is made: if it is not a firm principle to recover all the costs incurred by the Customs Service where users can be identified, then it ill behoves the minister and his government to pretend otherwise. In all logic, you could not do so, anyway. We know this government is as much in favour of pulling down non‐tariff barriers in its quest for fair trading internationally as it is of seeing tariff barriers removed.

If it wants to be able to go to the World Trade Organisation, it wants to go there with clean hands. But wait a minute—what have we got here? New, increased and hefty charges on imports of a non‐tariff kind. There must be some mistake, surely. This is not what successive Commonwealth governments have espoused in recent times. What would the Cairns Group say? These are amongst the most cynically explained and stupidly argued pieces of legislation that it has been my misfortune to come across in 18 years in this parliament.

If the government is sincere, why can't it simply say that it needed the revenue to go towards the elimination of Labor's legacy of a $10 billion underlying deficit? Admittedly, it would also have needed to confess to ripping $46 million off consumers by way of an indirect tax by another name, and that is contrary to if not its election undertakings then at the very least the spirit of them. As it stands, the minister has resorted to a charade and has brought no credit to him, his government, coalition colleagues or this House.
