(3) The Government does not intend to require unions to publish particulars of strike action in the mass media. However, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 contains provisions relating to the notification of `protected' industrial action, and provisions to minimise the disruptive effects of industrial action on essential services.

The Bill provides for a limited right to engage in industrial action or to lock out employees in the negotiation of single‐business certified agreements. For industrial action or a lockout to be regarded as protected action (that is, free from certain civil liability) it must take place during a bargaining period, which is initiated by a party given written notice to each other party and to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) about their intention to reach an agreement. Industrial action or a lock out must also meet other conditions to be protected, including that it has been preceded by a genuine attempt to reach agreement, and notice must be given to the relevant party about the proposed industrial action.

Where such industrial action is threatening to endanger the life, personal safety or health, or welfare of the population or a part of it, or to cause significant damage to the Australian economy or an important part of it, the AIRC can terminate the bargaining period. The AIRC is then required to conciliate and, if conciliation is unsuccessful and the AIRC considers it appropriate, to arbitrate. Any industrial action or lockout that persists following the termination of a bargaining period is not protected action, and would be liable to the range of remedies and sanctions available for illegitimate industrial action.

There is also a limited right to engage in industrial action or to lock out employees in the negotiation of Australian workplace agreements. Immunity from civil liability in respect of such industrial action or lockouts is conditional upon giving notice to the other party of the intention to take the action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the aircraft noise reduction project involving the insulation of homes in Sydney achieved its objective, particularly in the inner‐west area.
(2) Has the project fallen short of its target.
(3) What progress has been made to acquire residences in the most noise affected areas.
(4) What progress has been made to insulate schools and public buildings from noise effects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. 85% of those who responded to a recent homeowners survey offered positive comments and felt that the attenuation of their home had been successful. Early results indicate that the Project is achieving the expected reductions in noise level consistent with the type of building construction and the treatment applied. Homeowners are being approached in batches. To date over 1506 homeowners have been directly invited to participate. 1153 homeowners have indicated an interest in participating in the scheme; 449 residences have been insulated and a further 522 have commenced the process.

(2) No. To date progress has been consistent with milestones agreed with the Department of Transport and Regional Development. The announced program to the north of the airport is for 4400 houses and an initial group of 350 houses is being insulated to the west of the airport pending the announcement of the new airport operating conditions. Response rate and timing of the work is largely determined by the individual homeowner and the response rate has been increasing as people are becoming more confident in the effectiveness of the insulation.
(3) Considerable progress has been made towards acquiring the 150 eligible residences:

PARA.TAB: 123 houses have already been acquired;
a further 8 owners have agreed on the terms of sale;
the owners of another 13 houses have expressed interest in participating and have sought valuation advice;
6 owners have not responded to communications from the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: Acquired houses are being demolished. 75 houses and one block of 12 flats have already been demolished and the sites grassed. A further 13 houses are under demolition and the remainder are in preparation for demolition.
The acquisition program is voluntary. The offer, which is open to the end of 1996, allows owners to relocate at their convenience.

Valuations are based on fair market value as if the house was not in an area seriously affected by aircraft noise and residents are entitled to seek an independent valuation at Commonwealth expense. If an agreement on the price cannot be reached the matter can be referred to the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists for an independent valuation review.
The average settlement price of the houses is $215,305.

(4) The program to insulate schools, childcare centres, healthcare centres and churches is well advanced. Sixteen schools, two TAFE colleges and 20 pre schools have been noise attenuated. Overall, exceptionally good results have been achieved. Insulation of Newington College is to be completed by February 1998. Work has commenced on the first two buildings. Concept designs and technical briefs are complete for all eight nursing homes/aged care facilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Telephone Interpreter Service be reduced as a result of financial measures announced in the Budget; if so, in which area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No financial measures were announced in the Budget which affected the Translating and Interpreting Service (TIS) directly.

However, TIS forms part of the Immigration and Multicultural Affairs portfolio, and derives its funding from within the Department's Running Costs appropriation, supplemented by revenue received from TIS's fee‐paying clients.

In 1996‐97, funding for Commonwealth departments and agencies has been reduced due to both the on‐going application of the `efficiency dividend' (‐1%), plus an across‐the‐board cut in Running Costs (‐2%). Reductions such as these, impact on the TIS funding base.
TIS's three functions—translation, on‐site interpreting, and telephone interpreting services—continue to be provided as they were pre‐Budget.
